My husband walked in and didn't have much luck with the hostess!  She yelled, "it'll be at least 30 minutes...the line starts there!!! So we left saying, that one is going on YELP!  Arrrrg!
author: Audrey M.

description: This place is ok.....hopefully you aren't looking for authentic Mexican food. I've been here several times always giving them the benefit of the doubt that it will taste more authentic. But it has yet to get up to par. The rice tilt really tastes like rice-a-roni and the taco shells definitely taste store bought. However, the service is good and I do enjoy the atmosphere. Great bar as well.
author: Jennifer W.

description: This place is a lot of fun. The margaritas are really good. The bartenders are always nice. Bring in a buddy and split a platter.
author: Tim M.

description: Been trying to find a good restaurant near my house and came across this one on yelp. Went with my sister a few days ago, and it was awesome. Everything was great. We got their famous margaritas- 6-7$ for a very potent one. I got veggie fajitas and they were perfect. The portions were massive- so I definitely had some yummy left overs to bring home. The service was spot on, also. So glad I found this place- It'll definitely be my pick for Mexican food in the Inner Richmond.
author: Mellodee G.

description: You get an immense amount of food for a decent price, and the margarita portions are very generous
author: Shmevus P.

description:
Hands Down. Without a doubt. My favorite Mexican in SF.

What you will not get here:
-Hip vibe
-Fancy pants "mexican food"
-Tex Mex
-Arrogant waiters
-Watery drinks

What you will get here:
-Neighborhood joint vibe
-Simple, classic, homemade Mexican food
-Prompt, friendly, relax waiters
-STRONG drinks

I am not a tacqueria type girl, nor am I a huge fan of the scene-y "mexican joints" (read: Velvet C, Mama-C, Nick CT...)  I like to feel like I am sitting in an abuelas kitchen having comforting, yummy, down home Mexican food.  

Worth checking out if you want a relaxed and pleasant Mexican dinner with a tequila buzz on the side.
author: Gabrielle J.

description: The margaritas were good and strong and the server was nice and friendly.  Those are the pluses about this place.  The food however was crappy.  For $18+ I got the garlic shrimp entree.  That consisted of 6 medium sized shrimp, shredded iceberg lettuce topped with tomato sauce, dried up refried beans topped with burnt cheese and white rice.  The entire bill was $85 and that was ridiculously overpriced.  If I go back it will be for the margaritas and nothing more.
author: Heather S.

description:
Plunk your ass at the bar for a great margarita in the early evening.

The clientele can be phrat, avoid, avoid avoid.
author: Helena L.

description:
This place is your average Mexican Restaurant serving non-Mexican customers. Huge plates, lots of cheese, lots of chips and salsa, and all the different combinations of tortilla/meat/rice/beans/salsa/cheese you heart desires. 

This place is fun. The atmosphere is very relaxed and not pretentious. However, the service was sub-par and slow and the food was only ok. It's definitely what you'd find in the middle of the Richmond district. I'd say go to places closer to the Mission. One that stands out in my mind is Don Ramon's in the SoMa. 

Anyway, I would still recommend this place if you're in the area. You get tons of freshly fried chips and homemade salsa which is good enough. However, you can definitely get better. In this neighborhood though, this might be your best option.
author: Rylan C.

description:
Tia's was my most favorite Mexican restaurant in my old 'hood (oh, how I miss the Richmond District)

The chips and salsa are yummy!  The chicken flautas are the business!!!  And their fresh margaritas are hands down THE best in the 'hood... made with good quality tequila and FRESH lime juice (not the nasty bottled stuff).  

It's a great neighborhood restaurant where you end up becoming part of the Tia's family... I always make sure to stop by Tia's for my favorite staples whenever I'm back in the 'sco!
author: Christine Z.

description:
I have lived 3 blocks away from this restaurant for over a year and last night was my first AMAZING experience at tia margaritas!!  
  my friend and i sat at the bar and immediately ordered chips, salsa y guacamole to accompany our margaritas.  Not only was the bartender top notch in the entertainment department, he mixed up some fine house margaritas!  
We ended up ordering a 3-item combo plate to share: chile relleno, shrimp enchilada, and a shrimp taco...delish!  
  I seriously am punching myself for not having gone there before last night!! The missing star is due to beef, chicken, and shrimp being the only options... i love al pastor! boohoo!  Despite that,  I will be returning again soon!
author: Laura M.

description:
This is a bit of an upscale Mexican joint, at least in terms of price (that sounds kind of funny - an "upscale Mexican restaurant"...). 

TMMR is a deceptively large restaurant, known for its individually-crafted margaritas. While I didn't have a margarita tonight, I was certainly in the minority, as almost every other patron was (seemingly) enjoying their frosty beverages. 

The food was pretty standard, but I'm still in a bit of a tizzy about the prices. In the "light-eater" section, a small burrito (with some rice and beans) runs you $10.75. In my book, that's too expensive for Mexican food. 

I did, however, find the bartender quite funny and the atmosphere was enjoyable. Regardless, the nice ambiance won't save TMMR from its insanely high prices - I'll be looking elsewhere.
author: Tom A.

description: Great place. Laid-back atmosphere, friendly waitstaff. Food is DELICIOUS and the margaritas are bomb. Only complaint is that it's a bit expensive if you're a cheapskate like me. Nevertheless, Tia's is a fun place and definitely worth it!
author: Laura F.

description: Please change your service if you want more customers...from my previous experience at bars and restraunts they have CUSTOMERS come first always! This place unfortunately does not offer it. Go to the blue fin lounge (across the street) they take care of you well and make sure you are happy.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I'm a fan, I love it, its the best mexican food I've tasted that is almost like the REAL STUFF!!! My roommate and I love walking up sitting at the bar with a margarita in one hand and  a taco in the other. 
I really wish they werent as expensive,but still good and I still find myself going back expecially on friday nights.
author: Veronica V.

description: I *really* want to like this place. It's in the neighborhood, it's been there for years, it serves mexican food and has a full-service bar. What's not to like right? The drinks are strong, the food is decent but the service is hit and miss... too often miss. I now only sit at the bar, because I don't want to get stuck with a crabby, slow waitress who forgets what I order and couldn't care less about quality of service.
author: David G.

description:
Tia Margarita's Mexican Restaurant is ok. It's decent Mexican food in an area with not many Mexican restaurants. 

The decor and family feel completely reminds me of Don Jose's Mexican Restaurant, which is a family favorite. Although the atmosphere is reminiscent of D.J.'s the food is not. Don't get me wrong, it wasn't terrible it just wasn't great Mexican food and there wasn't anything at the menu that stood out or made my mouth water. The chips and salsa were even mediocre. I also felt as though it was kind of pricey for a bland Mexican restaurant. 

The plus is that the food came out at lightening speed and fed my hungry belly. 

They do have a decent selection of cold cold beers and the bar seemed to be crackin'. 

Our waitress was spectacular though. I don't remember her name but she so sweet and hilarious.

It was very busy and as I looked around and observed the crowd I noticed it was a mix of older folks, families and young people in business casual attire. I came to the conclusion that it's probably a good happy hour spot or last minute dinner choice for regular's and people living in the area that have grown to love it. 

This place is pretty much what you would expect from a Mexican Restaurant in the Richmond: not great Mexican food.
author: Denise S.

description: Very friendly, good service but the food was mediocre at best.  Tacos in preformed shells, chicken filling tasteless and  rather non exiistentt.  A big disappointment.  But their Margs are good.  Go for a drink but that's all.
author: Linda S.

description:
Great food.
Great drinks.
Amazing service.
HUGE portions.
You will be satisfied on every level.
author: alex l.

description:
My parents took me here because they absolutely adore Mexican food. They also live for cheap (and abundant) good eats. My dad was excited that we made reservations and got a table "before it got really packed".

Couldn't stop eating those chips!!! The red salsa is way mild and the green one has a good spice to it. I ordered the fajita platter which turned out to be HUGE. The meat was very well seasoned and grilled. I'm glad it doesn't come on the sizzling platter...I somehow always manage to get splattered on!!

Also couldn't peel my eyes from the ballgame on the TV. Extra points for being able to eat and watch tv.
author: Torie Y.

description:
Prices are high for what you get here. Girlfriend was disappointed in her salad, and I left hungry after eating my fajitas. Fajitas were decent, but nothing memorable. 

The food isn't terrible or anything, just not very delicious either. Average dining here.
author: Mike M.

description:
I enjoyed this place but wouldn't be my first choice when trying to pick a place to dine. There wasn't anything particularlly bad about it, I just wasn't over the moon about it.

The service was eh... They rushed us in ordering which I HATE because clearly if I haven't ordered yet I don't know what I want. 

They give you chips and salsa to munch on before the meal which is nice!
I ended up ordering Tia Margarita Special Enchiladas which were actually pretty tasty. 
I also ordered a blended double margarita which was the best part of the meal!!

we sat in the back of the restaurant but in the front they have a bar and TV so I could see myself going there again to watch a Giants game and have some drinks with friends.
author: Thea M.

description:
This place reminds me of the sit-down, old-style Mexican places I grew up on in SoCal.  Just the decor and waitstaff give off that vibe, maybe the clientele too, who appreciate the "traditional" service. 

Although the food isn't on par with some of those places down south, it's quality Mexican food and they give you lots of it too. I don't know what others are talking about, but the service has always been good here and the margaritas have been above average.

You're probably better off trying this place out before Tommy's down the street . No crazy wait with great food and service.
author: Art O.

description:
My experience with Tia Margarita involves my volleyball team coming in after a long night of playing and getting several rounds of chips and tequila shots til we're ready to stumble home. The one and only reason we ever came here is because it was literally right down the block from the gym.

But to be frank, this place is about as un-Mexican as a Mexican food restaurant can get. The margaritas are syrup and ice, the food is runny and overcooked, and the waiters look like they're pissed you ever dared to give them business. Outside of those cons, the crowd is pretty friendly and they're always down for a neighborly chat. If you're in the area, without any mode of transportation, and have an allergy to Asian foods, then Tia Margarita is your best bet.
author: Anthony C.

description:
What pains me the worst is that we had my mom's birthday here, she deserves so much better! 

- The salsa tastes like ketchup
- The food tastes like a frozen dinner
- How do you screw up refried beans??

One star because the older waittress was sweet and accomodating.
author: K G.

description:
My Android phone and Tia's saved my life. Well, sorta...hear me out.

So, when I moved to SF, I got a place in Outer Richmond... but all my stuff was still in LA for another month. So there I was, in January, stuck in a big, empty house in a strange city with a broken furnace (stay with me here) and no furniture. No bed, no chair. Just a blanket on the floor. 

Feeling particularly sorry for myself one night, I set out (in a downpour) to find somewhere to drink...well, eat and drink, but mostly drink. I pulled out my phone, and between the phone's GPS and a Yelp-ish application found Tia's. My life was saved.

Warm, inviting, and with *excellent* margaritas, Tia's pulled me out of my stupor, and now friends and I go there a few times every month. The chorizo and eggs dish is ridiculous in its amazingtude, and the carne asada equally great. (Portions are huge, so ask for extra tortillas.) 

Sit at the bar - especially if you look cold and miserable - the drink quality (which is already pretty high) jumps up to "really, have a drink" magnitude when you can look the bartenders directly in the eye.
author: Rob D.

description:
If giving 0 stars were an option, that's how many stars i would give this place.  My non PC description=whitewashed Mexican food.  We had a group of 10 and made a reservation a week ahead of time for 7pm.  We weren't seated until 8pm!  Crazy!  The food was mediocre; the beans came from a can and margaritas from a mix.  Sauza is their house tequila!  EWW!  Our waitress was beyond rude and kept getting our orders wrong.  We had to send back our plates many times.  We were over charged but because it took the waitress forever to come to our table, we just ended up paying our over priced meal and not giving a tip.  Don't waste your time!  This place SUCKS!  

The one good thing: Though the waitress is rude and incompetent, the table busers were friendly.
author: Lolo H.

description: I've been coming to Tia Margarita most of my life, and this place feels like home.  It's not fancy-pants mexican, it's just delicious, down-home, ample-portioned mexican.  It's not diet food and it's not meant to be.  Their salsa is the BEST.
author: K H.

description:
I was fortunate to be taken to this place a couple of days ago and I have to say that the food was pretty decent. For a more authentic taste that doesn't require you to head over to the Mission, I say Tia's hits the spot.
The portions were BIG and the refried beans and rice very good.
The only thing is, if you don't like onions, make sure you let them know because my Tia enchilada was very yummy, but had a lot of onions, which, even for this onion loving girl was pretty strong.
The classic margarita was strong and tasty and the chips and salsa spicy, like I want it.

The atmosphere was nice and cozy and the service attentive.

I will definitely go back.
author: Kathy K.

description:
Huge portions! Even the plates themselves are massive!

Good chips and salsa. The burrito plate comes with 2 burritos and they're big - so much food.The enchiladas rancheros were only OK.
The beef is ground, ugh, but the chicken is shredded and good. 

Service was fine.
author: Rachel G.

description:
Two words: Hot Garbage.

I had to give two stars, though, because we live close by and my daughter looooves their Shirley Temples.
author: Neile R.

description: The food is great. I really like the neighborhood feel about this restaurant. I got to say that the margarita's weren't anything to write home about. But I plan to go back for seconds! The chicken enchiladas are really good! :)
author: Ryan H.

description:
i have seen ed hardy here.  he lives up the street from me.  I live a block away.  and do my laundry across the street.
watch out.  you will get sloshed at this place.  the food is similar to tommys up the street.  just good warm chips, salsa, refried beans, melted cheese, i usually get enchiladas or tamales, and they are both drenched in sauce, which is good to me.  everything is warm, hearty and scoopy.
i have thrown up in the planters across the street, because the margaritas snuck up on me.  
they do take out.
their bar area is great.  they have trivia nights that apparantly are pretty challenging and lively.
thanks for reading!
author: yayoi s.

description:
***Review strictly for the margaritas and the bartender***

We had just come from Tommy's after a round.  Promptly seated at the bar.  Fresh chips and spicy salsa glided in front of us.

A single blended and a double on the rocks was ordered.  And they were delicious and refreshing, and definitely gives you a good buzz.

The bartender is THE nicest guy.  But I think he concocted a back story of me and my friend in his head (that we were married and left the kids at home to sneak out for a drink).  So we played along.
author: Jenny L.

description: Been to this restaurant twice over the past month or so and neither time have had to wait more than ten minutes for a table.  The food was great both times and very generous portions.  Waitresses were generally quite good and attentive.  The margaritas were made with fresh limes and heavy on the tequila.  Overall a casual, yet very good, neighborhood restaurant with reasonable prices.
author: Kent W.

description:
This place is WHACK. The service people are weird weird weird. As in not normal, comforting, pleasant, or enjoyable. They make me feel like they dont even want my service. Granted the last time it was a Saturday night and they were decently busy, but times are tough and this place cant afford to lose a customer! 

Unfortunately I have not tried the margaritas as crazy as that sounds. Seriously though, how freakin hard is it to make a margarita? I made one tonight in 5 seconds for half the price...a shitload more tequila too. You cannot give this place too many props for a stupid margarita. The food is white washed, im pretty sure the rice is Rice-a-Roni. The salsa tastes like plain tomato sauce. Their taco shells werent even home made! I can make more legit Mexican food at home, and Im Italian! In fact, I challenge them to a Mexi throw down!

This place is such a scam, it looks cool and feels right, but it isnt. The crowd there is pretty lame too. They remind me of oatmeal - hot and boring. I have way to much personality, and good taste, to go back to this place. Next time Im going to Tommys.
author: Holl T.

description:
The margaritas are very affordable and drinkable: and that's a relief in tourist- and yuppie-cursed San Francisco where most margies are overhyped, underpoured ripoffs. The food at Tia is classic "old school" Mexican, meaning that the menu appears to have been created and is still cooked by old white men for working class white people, and the decor and concept also created by white men from back in the day when Mexican food was exotic in SF. The booths are awesome. 

Food is fair to good, not great, there is definitely better and much more authentic Mexican food in SF, but the portions are huge and the atmosphere is always lively. The tacos are decent. The bar is awesome. Order the double margie. The chips and salsa are bottomless, too!
author: Josh B.

description:
I'm actually surprised the stars on this restaurant are only about 3.5. I find them to be at least a 4, and if I was judging purely on the chile rellenos, I would give them a 5! 

Tia Margarita is a delicious neighborhood restaurant and bar. I have been here several times and it is a common suggestion among my friends.  The restaurant looks smaller than it actually is, which is nice because I have never waited for a seat (but I'm sure on weekends it is a bit busier.)  The food is nothing too original (Mexican staples: burritos, tacos, enchilladas, quesadillas, etc) but everything they have is delicious!

I specifically recommend the chile rellenos which are probably the best I have ever had!

The margaritas are delicious as well and if they aren't your thing, they have a full bar.  

The waitstaff is friendly and will refill my chips and salsa until my heart and stomach are content! Prices are reasonable- a little more than you would usually pay if you were going to a taqueria ($11-14 per entree) but they give you an enormous round plate of food. My test for the amount of food is always whether or not it fills up my boyfriend, who has been known to eat his fair share... This place passes the test! 

Bottom line:
-parking is not too bad
-restaurant and bar combined
-not overly crowded
-delicious food
-order the chile rellenos
author: Jean K.

description:
I don't think I have one positive thing to say about our experience and that's sad because I love Tex-Mex.  I was so excited that we accidentally "found" this place.  Now I know why I'd never heard of it.

Summary:
* It was around 5 pm, so they weren't busy, but they took forever to seat us.  
* They only had 2 highchairs, both in use by one of the few tables there.  
* The place itself is old & dingy.
* The service was incredibly slow and the waiter was rude.  
* The food's presentation was ok, but the food itself was terrible.

I picked at the edible things on my plate.  Our daughter usually devours Mexican rice, but she took 1 bite of it and no more.  Even the guacamole was gross -- over-onioned and kind of warm.

In the end, we didn't eat most of our food and we didn't take it with us.  2 beers, a burrito, enchilads, a child's plate, and a side of guacamole was ~$60 before tip. The quality was in the $20-$25 range. 

No question: we'll never go back.
author: Debra H.

description: Went once and didn't have the best experience.  I ordered a margarita and it was so strong it was almost undrinkable - which normally isn't a complain but it was pretty gross.  On my entree my black beans were not cooled all the way through.  Overall it was pretty bland.
author: Sam E.

description: Crappy margaritas, mediocre food. 1 extra star for the garlic shrimp.  For all the amazing Mexican options in San Francisco, coming here is an exercise in laziness.
author: Todd G.

description: Not sure that this place even gets 1 star - food was awful, service horrid and decor, well, too dark to see anything - as one reviewer put it, "at least we didn't get sick"
author: Richard D.

description: Very good mexican food, definitly try the flautas, they are so good. Also their margaritas are very good. At first sip I thought, 'this is not too great, it seems like it isn't very strong'. Then....after the halfway mark I realize how loud I am talking, and YES, the margaritas are fabulous!!!!! =)
author: Kimberly H.

description:
BEST margaritas in San Francisco, hands down!  And I am such a snob when it comes to margs.
Get a double.   I swear you'll think, "I'm not going to even feel it, it's so small" then you taste it and it doesn't even taste like tequila, then after two, you'll be thinking of friends to call for  a ride home.  They are SO tasty and strong!
Fun to sit at the bar and drink margs and order dinner.  I love the tacos.
I love Tia's
author: Fresh M.

description: I lived in Texas for 4 years and became a Tex-Mex snob. It took me 3 years of living in San Francisco to find this place and now I won't go anywhere else! I LOVE Tia Margarita's. Their margaritas are as fresh as can be- they squeeze the limes before your eyes. NO MIX is used, therefore there's no gross, sweet taste. My husband even likes them and he's not a margarita fan. The food is great as well. I love the special enchilada.. very cheesy and delicious. Plus, they're always showing the Giants games in the bar. If you haven't been here and you love Tex-Mex, you MUST try it out! You won't be disappointed.
author: Turi M.

description: Worst margarita I've EVER had and I've had them ALL!  I didn't even taste anything but blended water and low budget tequila.  I'd comment on the food but it's hard not to start with the worst, most mean server in the world.  She's been there forever they say.  I asked if she was "Tia?" - no.  She was rude to me, my mom and my guests.  She couldn't hear (had hearing aides in) nor could my mom.  My mom couldn't hear her and she couldn't hear my mom so the server got increasingly mad and walked away.  I asked her what she reccomended and she said "the peanutbutter and jelly" and walked away.  It's a joke of a place.  Big portions, the food is not anything to write home about.  The chips are bad.  One of the salsas is way too hot, and did I mentioned their name sake, the margarita, top shelf, is the WORST I've ever had?  Save your time and money and go elsewhere!
author: Lori G.

description:
Ok...I come here only because I can walk, have a couple of pretty good margaritas that actually contain alcohol and walk home...

The food is  bad, but not sooo bad after a margarita...?

It's overpriced, and the staff, especially the hostess, does not hide the fact that she really doesn't like people...

I haven't seen the abusive older spanish waitress my last few trips...the one that if you speak spanish to, will only speak english (kind of) or if you speak english to, she only speaks spanish...

I don't know, I keep going back even though it all sucks except for the booze...I guess I like punishment and can finally see the humor in it after 20 years of living with in walking distance?
author: C. S.

description:
Tia Margarita would be fantastic if their food was good. The restaurant and bar area is fun and charming. The light outside draws you in---unlike the Greenpeace peeps in front of my work (no offense miss). However, I was not impressed by the lackluster food. 

I had the two taco dish, one chicken and one beef, and they were both bland. $1 for sour cream on the side?? Come on now. 

Highlight of my experience here was the chips. They give you lots of them.
author: Jackie M.

description: I love this place! The food and margaritas are just awesome. I have never had a bad meal here. We are always greeted with a warm and friendly welcome every time we visit--which is about once a month because my friends and I are so hooked on this place. I generally get the shredded beef taco or the pollo asado because they are my absolute favorites. The portions are big; the chips and salsa are fresh and delicious. The service is great, and the food is always excellent. Parking in the area is a royal pain, and oftentimes there is a bit of a wait, but that doesn't stop us from going to our favorite Mexican restaurant in all of San Francisco! The margaritas will knock you out!
author: Denny G.

description:
We moved into the neighborhood in March, 2011.  For an entire year now we have been eying this place.  Finally, we decided to give it a try.  We ordered a single ice margarita and some chicken tacos and a tamale.  We could not get beyond two sips of the margarita.  The food was equally bad.  I prefer my taco truck in Redwood City where I can get three incredibly delicious tacos for under $5.

Okay, my daughter insists that not all was EQUALLY bad because I stole some of her black beans ( I must have liked it to go for it, no?) AND we did enjoy the chips, salsa and guac.  This review is updated to TWO *.  If it was possible I would only give it 1.5*.
author: Masud K.

description:
I have been going to this place off and on for years.  The staff is always friendly and I remember the portions being rather large.  I love the enchiladas they serve there.  They are absolutely delicious! I always remember the staff members smiling and looking like they're having a good time.  

The place is rather dark and you can enjoy an intimate dinner with a small party.  

It has been a while since I have gone but I think about this place from time to time.  I think its time I go back.
author: Jennifer C.

description: The Tia has the best margaritas in the city...freshly squeezed lime juice and not sweetened!  The bartenders and wait staff are friendly and always accommodate us...with the kids or on a date night. The queso is decadent, and the chips are always fresh.  Always a great night!
author: Marisa R.

description:
LOVE Tia!  Great neighborhood Mexican restaurant!  I always order the flautas, yummy.  I have ordered the burritos as well and they are delish.  I can always tell a good Mexican restaurant based on the "free" chips and salsa they give to to start with and the salsa is fantastic!  Margaritas are great as well.  You walk in the place and you'll find the game (whatever the season...baseball, football, soccer) on at the bar.  
Again, great neighborhood restaurant and fabulous chips and salsa and margaritas.  I frequent this place....it's the shit!
author: Jacquelyn M.

description:
Don't get me wrong... I love all Mexican food. Throw something hot and cheesy in front of me and I will eat it.

It is, however, because of my deep love of Mexican food, that I am forced to be somewhat more critical of the establishments in which I choose to dine. My waistline, after all, does not authorize them all admittance to my elite list of regulars.

Why Tia's, sadly, will not be making the cut:

* Poor UI. Booth seating aligns the "U" of the bar - no problem there - but the hostess desk is located at the very far corner of said "U". Not at all convenient and very confusing for first timers.

* The chips were stale. Setting the mood with stale chips is not a well thought out move on your part Tia. The chip portion of the meal should be an easy A!

* The waitress was an enchilada Nazi. As soon as we sat down she asked us for our order, I asked for a minute, she counted out loud "1, 2, 3, 4... your minute is up," and proceeded to stare at me expectantly. She was 30% kidding, at most. 

* Tia's strategy seems to focus on quantity versus quality. While the food is only mediocre, you get a shit ton of it for the price. For $12 a pop, our plates were so large I had to ask that the stale chips be taken away to make room for our margaritas!

Also - this is a side note - what is up with every sit down Mexican restaurant in the Sunset being closed on Mondays? Did some secret council convene and decide to torture us by making our favorite comfort food unavailable on the hardest day of the week? This includes Tia Margaritas, Celia's, and Tommy's! Come on guys ...have a heart and rotate your days off as to not leave your loyal patrons without their Monday margs. Don't make me go to Chevy's.
author: Taylor E.

description: OK, this is a good "old school" type American/Mexican restaurant. Great chips, huge portions, fun bar with good people watching.  Actually a pretty big restaurant.  Food is good and for a Mexican food connoisseur like myself, it will do just fine in a Mexican food fix without going to the Mission or in my case, to Alameda to my all time favorite, La Penza Azul on Park Street.  Tia Margarita is a fun, casual joint for tasty mexican fare.
author: Andrea R.

description:
I do love a good sit-down Mexican restaurant.  This is a good one to hit after you spend an afternoon chasing small people at the CA Academy of Sciences.  The front room is all loungey christmas lights and booths.  The big back room is for those of us with kids and little time to lounge.

Service is fine, unless you get that one really slow (but nice) lady.  The food comes out quickly and it's tasty.  The green sauce is nice and zippy if you get the enchiladas.  And the margaritas are just fine.  Overall, I'd give Tia 3.5 estrellas.
author: Andi T.

description:
I have been going here for YEARS.  Ever since day one, I have never had a bad meal. My friend in LV loves to come here everytime she visits. 

Be sure to order a margarita, they can make you evening! I order one of the large combinations and take half of it home for lunch the following day.

I will continue to go as long as I can.
author: Cricket B.

description:
Best Margarita's in Town!

What else you need to know?
author: Kristina A.

description:
Its just alright...

Ordered a chile relleno and cheese enchilada combo. The enchilada sauce was nothing speciall but they do hook you up with the cheese. As for the chile relleno - if you have ever had a one from Jimboys it tastes EXACTLY like a Jimboys chile relleno. Dont get me wrong, I liked it. But, knowing I could spend half the price for a similar meal kinda rubs me the wrong way. For me the best part was the rice. I dont know what they do to it but I really liked it and it wasnt even in the style of spanish rice. 

In their defense, I came here with a group of about 15 and most of the people I was with liked their food. They really raved about the Flautas in particular. The margaritas are pretty good too.
author: Richard C.

description:
I really enjoying coming to Tia Margarita, because the food is good, and it always becomes on the funnier side because of the older waitress and asks the same thing to every person "chicken or beef" and also always seems to forget things!

The mexican hot chocolate is really good here, as is there quesdilla (however the quesdilla is a corn tortilla folded in half, and the meal comes with two, i normally order a third to fill me up).

It defiently is a fun little restaurant, and a little bit more of an older school of mexican food then what you always find today!

I must add too, i have been here a few times with larger groups and they have always been great about getting us in!

Parking can be the big pain
author: Noelle L.

description: If you need chest hair, have a Cadillac margarita, BAM!!!  Fresh lime juice, premium tequila and Grand Marnier...mmmmm, mmmm! The service is fantastic, warm and friendly. The food is not the best Mexican I've ever had but the chimichangas are tasty and BIG and their combo plates will leave you with yummy leftovers for days
author: Monica W.

description:
I started off with a margarita, reading others posts about "how fantastic they are." They are very strong and are not all that great tasting due to the guys uneven mixing of the ingredients. They pretty much start out by measuring using a shot glass and then just start pouring directly into the shaker almost blindfolded. Sure to get you wasted if that's what you want but not a classic tasty refreshment. I ordered the large combination plate and it was decent. Lacking in authentic Mexican flavor and tasted a little bland. The rice is certainly not anything like normal rice made in central or south America and tasted plain. 

The place is nice and casual and the service was excellent with friendly and funny very attentive staff, who seem to know their regular clientele. Restaurant was very busy at 7:20 pm on a Wednesday night. The food was reasonably priced with large portions, but just not that great.
author: Trev D.

description: I LOVE  this place. Friendly staff, good food (get the fajitas) and big portions. Antonio, the bar server, is awesome. My favorite neighborhood spot by far.
author: Sarah D.

description:
Order the double margarita on the rocks & after 2, you'll be good.... & def. munch on the chips/salsa if you're drinking more.

Things to think about:
-SMALL: if more than 3+, arrive early bc it's 1st come seating.
-PARKING: not much of it around.
-MENU: limited.
author: Star B.

description:
This wasn't good. 

I ate here mainly because it's near my home, and I see it all the time - riding my bike or driving by.

The food was pretty disappointing!  It didn't have much flavor, and it just reminded me of eating at a worse version of El Torito.  Even the chips were bad!  On top of that, it was expensive.

The only thing I liked was the ambiance - but that doesn't really matter when your food is boring.

SO, I don't think I'll be going back!
author: Liz C.

description: Hostess not so friendly unless ur her BFF. Good greasy food & powerful margys ! Bartender is awesome.
author: Peter H.

description: this review is solely for the chicken enchilada plate, which is what i get here every time. it comes on a huge plate so that it seems like you're getting a lot, but all the food items are pretty spread out. i still leave pretty full though! it comes with two enchiladas covered in melted cheese, rice, beans, and a salsa salad. i like everything! and i like how this is a neighborhood mexican restaurant that has survived for over fifty years! oh, and their complimentary chips and homemade salsa are also really good, we always ask for seconds (sometimes thirds).
author: Sabrina L.

description:
I really wanted to love Tia's. I live 5 blocks from it and there is nothing I enjoy more than great mexican food. I had heard mixed reviews about the place, but decided that I must try it for myself. This was a bad idea. 

After a long day of wild boar hunting with my dad we decided to quell our starving bellies at Tia's. We step into the restaurant, and surprisingly, it is not at all crowded on a Saturday night (bad sign). Nobody helps to seat us at first, but finally the bartender tells us to take any table. 

A sweet, yet awkward Irish waitress (love the accent) brought us menus. However, we then waited 20 minutes to get water and to order. This annoyance was tempered by the moderately good chips and salsa that a busser brought us. The chips were good, seemed fresh, but a little thick for my taste. The spicy salsa (they also have a non-spicy) was quite good, but didn't change the overall experience. 

I ordered the chicken enchiladas and my father ordered the burrito and chili relleno combo. All were bland and uninspired. As we worked through our food with sadness and dismay, a crowd of Irish folk developed all around. This was probably the highlight of the meal listening to them sing and drink loudly. Always a good time. Although, it was quite an odd sight seeing Irish people crowd up a mexican food restaurant. 

Overall, I will probably never go back to Tia's. Not because it was the worst thing I've ever tasted, but because with so many good restaurants in SF there are plenty of places to fill my tummy.
author: Thor M.

description:
I've always wondered about this place and finally decided to go give it a try last month or so after getting so tired of the regular taqueria food near my work place.

Once we walked in, we were greeted with the lovely old lady who I think is the owner. The atmosphere seemed really relaxing and I knew my dinner is gonna be amazing.

Started with some chips and salsa and chips and queso... Chips were served warm and salsa was a bite mild but not overly spicy.. I love how you can eat as much chips as you want because they just keep bring you more after your basket is done. The cheese was delicious.. It was very tasty, stringy, and yummy!

We kinda shared our entrees. So entrees included:
Chef's special-Pollo Asado, carne asada, and gambas (there was SO MUCH food on this plate it's crazy!)

The pollo (chicken) was thinly cut and served with scallions on top with a tangy marinade.. The chicken was not DRY and the flavor was great.

Carne asada (steak) had a little lime marinade with sauteed onions and chiles.

Gambas (shrimp) My favorite one on the plate! Lots of butter and garlic. YUM! 

Served with refried beans and rice.

Then there was the tamales. AMAZING tamales! They know how to make some good fucken tamales.. They are HUGE and yummy. Filled with lots of meat and my favorite part in a tamale is the corn shell, it was thick! That means there was a lot of corn shell for me to eat.!! 

Didn't try the margaritas but definitely will next time.

Great service, great atmosphere, great food = 5 stars! *****
author: Juliane N.

description:
My wife and I decided to try this place out last night...on our hunt for a good Mexican sit down restaraunt.  We were a little wary after reading the reviews on Yelp, but decided to give it a shot.  Not the best idea.

Our waitress was very nice, but really did not explain any of the dishes to us.  We are both vegetarian and it took literally 5 minutes to explain that to her...most of the time we just got a blank stare.  Finally after ordering 2  cheese enchiladas, she walks away and says, 'sounds good...2 CHICKEN enchiladas'!!!  WTF!!!  I ran down and corrected the order and she just laughed it off.

The food arrives pretty quickly and was not very good at all.  The portions were very large, but there seemed to be no flavor in our food.  The enchilada sauce completely lacked any flavor and the plate was below mediocre.  The salsa tasted like spaghetti sauce.

Overall, would not recommend this place to anyone.
author: Rajeev R.

description:
2.5 rounding up to 3 because of the red-pleather-cantina-fabulous decor in the Inner Richmond. 

I'm *still* full from last night's meal of beef fajitas, where I didn't eat the tortillas, hardly touched the beans and left about half the rice on the plate. 

The food was mediocre, the portion for one order is big enough for 2 people and the service is a tad step behind, but apart from that, TM is a fairly decent addition to the neighborhood.

I like that there are regulars who eat and drink here when they want a low-key night, and that my friend and I can walk in on any given Sunday and drink margaritas on the rocks until our livers turn bright green and explode.
author: May T.

description:
Tia Margarita is easy to miss. It looks like a house, doesn't have loud mariachi music blaring from inside, and doesn't blast the streets with lights. 

I walked in here with a friend after passing by numerous times. We ordered the appetizer combo and a Margarita. While we waited, we sipped on our drinks and ate some chips. They offered two salsas, a mango fruit flavored one and a spicy one. Both were good, but I preferred the fruit flavored one. You can also combine them for the best of both worlds.

When our food arrived, It turned out a lot better than I expected. We received small burritos, a quesadilla, empanadas, and a few other assortments that I forget. Good sizes, easily shared, and good quality. It wasn't the most authentic Mexican I've ever eaten, but for Americanized Mexican, it was pretty darn good -- a LOT better than Chevy's or any of the other chains. 

I left happy and decided I'd go back with more friends. The second time I went, we sat at the bar. I'll admit, I don't remember much. The bartender was nice, the drinks were generous, and the food didn't end up on the street, if you know what I mean.

Update (4/5/08) - I went back and it was a mad house. The waiters forgot our orders,  bartenders ignored us, and it was not quite the same experience. The margaritas were actually pretty bad? So we ordered some top shelf to see if there would be a difference -- nope. The food quality was different, too! Our sampler's empanada's looked like fried cheese bread. Maybe it was a weekend, but this inconsistancy is scary. I'm downgrading my rating...
author: Jason C.

description: DONT BOTHER GOING..... the only good thing about this place was the waitress and her willingness to please us. As for the bartender Pedro, he just needs to get fired!!!!  His rudeness accompanied by the lack of customer service from Jennifer (the owner's niece) was downright insulting.  You'd think that for the prices they charge, one would be getting good service and edible food.  Lesson learned: check help before eating anywhere.
author: Cecilia M.

description:
Lost in the blur of SF taquerias is the fact that there's precious few *sit-down* Mexican restaurants in the city--I could probably count the ones I know of on the fingers of one hand.  If you do find yourself sitting down for south-of-the-border fare, it's probably upscale Peruvian or down-home Salvadoran or some such.  Maybe Mexi-joints have been deemed too suburban?  Granted, if your menu is limited to burritos, enchiladas and fajitas, with obligatory sides of rice and beans, then you're about as Mexican as Panda Express is Chinese.  If only some bold chef would see this as a challenge and open a place specializing in authentic Mexi-dishes (perhaps even limit it to a specific region), I'm confident our pretentious citizenry would eat it up.

But in the meantime, Mrs M likes her enchiladas, and I like my free bottomless chips and salsa, so I figured we'd give this a shot.  Food was good but unmemorable--except that they gave us butter with the tortillas!  I was baffled, but Wes M never turns down free fat (seriously, I brought home some Tennessee bacon grease in a ziploc bag from the presidential debate party I went to--long story).

The other problem is that, for a restaurant that has "Margarita" in the name and a $9+ "double" margarita on the menu, it turned out to be disappointingly small, and I think Maria is right that they're pretty weak too (tasty though).  

So in the end, Velvet Cantina remains the undisputed king of the limited competition in this category.  But TM is very like VC in one way: the restaurant has two rooms, and the one with the bar has by far the superious ambiance (indeed, TM's bar is a bit reminiscent of Zam Zam, don't you think?)
author: Wes M.

description:
Really? I wanted to like it but i can't bring myself to give it anything but one star. And honestly that star is for the decor and how close it is to my house. First they were out of tamales, so i ordered an enchilada. I didn't realize that you could screw up an enchilada but apparently you can. I didn't love the margarita, it was okay. Nothing to write home about. 

Skip it.
author: cathryn t.

description:
I definitely had to try this restaurant because its a block away from where I dwell. I wasn't disappointed like I anticipated. Which is a great thing! 

When you first walk into the restaurant, you are right in front of the crowded bar area. Crowds are a good sign. You have to wind your way around the bar area to the left to get to the hostess stand.

The dining area is dim, but fits the ambience. The mexican music and decor truly makes you feel like you are in a mexican restaurant. Even the fans twirling over head gives you the feeling that you are in Mexico on a hot, hot day despite being in the foggy outer Richmond.

The margaritas are just what a margarita should be. I had a single on the rocks. Whew! Now, I know why the bar area is crowded. These are great and potent with alcohol. Perfect margaritas. The chips and salsa were great while waiting for the food. They give you two types of salsa, one is hot and one is mild. I liked the hot salsa, but the mild is good, too.

I had the chicken fajitas and was not disappointed. The strips of chicken were full of flavor and the tortillas came nice and steamy hot. My boyfriend had the enchiladas and he enjoyed them just as much as I enjoyed my fajitas. The portions are huge, so you must come here hungry and ready to eat.

Overall: Food is okay and the margaritas are tasty.
author: Liz K.

description:
Dear Richmond District, 

 I love you so much. You have the best parks, views are awesome but where's all  the Mexican restaurants? There's Gordo's which is ok. Pancho's doesn't hit the spot. Tommy's is always busy. Tia Margarita's I guess you'll have to do. 

This place is the bomb! They got huge portions and the food is delicious! Some previous review wrote about a trick with different sized plates and portions. Their plates my differ but I assure you that their portions are huge, I promise I personally love their combo platters and chimichangas. Their food is solid. 

I never had a problem with their service. I like the place and they got a bar so you can keep the drinks coming all night long. Don't get me wrong.. if you're not sitting at the bar the kids will have fun here too. It's an awesome place folks and even better that it's a public service that their located in the Richmond.
author: Dan T.

description: Stopped in on a rainy Tuesday evening after a friend had a hankering for some Mexican food. I had never been before, but was excited to give it a try. Definitely seems like a local spot. Family friendly/lots of characters at the bar. Started off our meal by ordering some Margaritas, it's a Tuesday after all. Opted for the single over the double. Our margs were shamed by the doubles when brought to the table on the same tray. Next time will go with the double. Fresh hot chips and salsa came to our table (a little late for our liking) we were looking forward to those. Green(hot) salsa was by far my favorite over the red(mild) option. I ordered the tia margarita special enchiladas. Absolutely delicious! I am a connoisseur of enchiladas so I was glad to find some tasty ones. The service was a bit lax, but other than that pretty good.
author: Jackie B.

description:
The double margaritas are deliciously dangerous, and you get so much food for the price. I love getting the combos, and nuking my burrito the next day for lunch.

No, it's not authentic, but as long as you sit in the bar room, the ambiance is 1,000% better than Tommy's. I've been here twice now with my Mexican-American and Panamanian-American friends and they don't give a crap that it's not authentic cause it's still delicious, and a very fun place to hang. 

One word of caution: don't go too early or you'll be surrounded by kids.
author: Cherry P.

description:
Yo le doy CINCO ESTRELLAS!!!!

Wow, this place is great. I mean really great. But that's only if you like reeeeeally greasy traditional Mexican food, which I do. (And by the way I think you're just absolutely crazy if you don't.) 

The horseshoe bar in the front area is great if you just want to sit and chill and drink your margarita with some amigos. Or if you just wanna come solo, I'm sure you'll end up meeting some cool people by the end of the night! 

I like to sit at the U-booth tables that surround the bar to eat dinner. The food is absolutely gluttonous and deeeeeelicious. I feel like a pig and curse myself for eating so much by the time it's time to go! But it's just that good. 

And the margaritas-- the margaritas!!! Don't even bother with the single. You WILL order the double. It's not even very much bigger than the single, and compared to the plates of food they give you (which are enormous), you'll want a big ass margarita to go along with it!!!
author: Chantal H.

description:
I really wish I could write an in-depth review on Tia; however, I was slightly under the influence ... Slightly, okay.?...  Well, maybe slightly under the influence when I walked in ... By the time we left -- i was downright drunk.  What, you ask, I thought you were a proud and dedicated father Lindonisia... Let me tell you something about parenting, sometimes daddys drink...especially when there at Tia's.
So back to the review:

Drinkies:
What I can tell you is that the bartenders rule the margs..Potent with out being over the top good without being sheshe. Ya know.

Food:
We ordered the chicken fajitas (with *no* oil per Moi ... I like to make it difficult) - good stuff. Again, maybe we were a bit easier to please due to our slightly intoxicated state ... But I do recall these being tasty!

So, considering my state of mind, if I do say so myself, the review should give you exactly what you want .
author: Lindonesia S.

description:
Yum- yum- yum! 
Frozen Strawberry Margaritas- delicious
Sampler Appetizer- worked as a meal for 3 people
Salsa is amazing- I'd go back just for the chips and salsa
Service was very friendly  
Reasonably priced in comparison to the large portions 

I'd definitely recommend Tia's to a friend.
author: Melinda Q.

description:
Infinitely better than that other place up the street (you know what I'm talking about) but still pretty mediocre plated Mexican food. Still, It's an excellent place to bring an East Coaster -aka land of bad mexican food- for some conversation and inside jokes when you don't feel like heading over to La Mision.  They use real mexican queso in their enchiladas (none of this melted shredded cheese) which was very nice and the guac was super yummy but the meal as a whole was not super spectacular. However, I loved feeling like I was completely secluded from Clement Street and I've decided I'm the tackiest person alive because if I could combine the interior of this restaurant with the interior of The Page, I would have my dream house. 

Margs were weak and you know how I know this? It's 1:00am, I'm still awake and I haven't made any humiliating phone calls, text messages or emails. And I had two of them. And I had doubles. I should have at least emailed my Danish ex boyfriend at this point.  "Jeg elkser dig, elksling! Please take me away to your magical land of aquavit and smorgasbord!!!!"
author: Maria D.

description: I wanted to like it as much as I like Tommy's, but it just isn't so. I am NOT one of those people who complains about Americanized food- I am ALL FOR cheeeeesy enchiladas. But how do you mess that up?? They tasted really bland. And the refried beans tasted burnt or something. If you like your margaritas on the 99.9% tequila side, then you will like the margaritas here. Sorry, I'm not hardcore enough, I do like a little fresh squeezed lime and flavor with my margs. The chips were fresh and yummy though. I liked the huge round plates that the food came on, I just wish I had liked the food more. I don't really think I'm going to try it again though. Back to Tommy's!
author: Libbi K.

description: A Richmond gem!  The food is nothing fancy, but the atmosphere, staff, and overall environment are classic.  Margaritas are delicious, as are the chips and salsa. If I could buy that salsa, I would.  A con is that they always close pretty early. It's a family joint, after all, but most times I've gone there we only have time for one drink before they close.  But the drinks are quite strong, so maybe that's wise.
author: Erin D.

description: Love this place! It is a feel good experience. Just down home San Francisco establishment with a locals vibe and great energy. Good people and good, fast service and tasty food.
author: Liv A.

description:
Because I'm an avid fan of margaritas and sit-down Mexican restaurants, Tia Margarita had been on my list to try for a while.  

The margaritas were just what I was craving: strong, generous sizes, and in crazy cactus glasses.  Nothing pretentious, here.  They completely hit the spot.  $9 for a large.

The food was just OK--nothing to write home about but certainly nothing to complain about either.  I got their "signature enchiladas" and thought they were pretty bland run-of-the-mill cheese enchiladas.  Any taqueria in the Mish will do better.

The service was excellent.

If I lived in the neighborhood, I'd probably eat here all the time.  But if I'm going to drive all the way out to the Avenues for Mexican Food, I'm going to brave the wait at Tommy's, instead.
author: Amy A.

description:
i live in the mission and trek out to the Richmond for Mexican food??  

But seriously, Tia's serves my favorite margaritas in the city. Not too sweet, not too strong... juuust right!  The food is good but not spectacular. It's their margarita's that get me. delish!
author: Shayna N.

description:
This restaurant is literally the reason why I've finally made a Yelp account.. to advise you NOT to eat here. Unless you want to get boozed up because that is probably the only reliable thing here, strong drinks. 

Why? Let me explain. 
**Poor service
Rude! Rude! Rude!
Not only did our waitress ignore our request for waters, only concerned with what we wanted from the bar ($), but she literally sat at the table across from our booth watching us while we figured out what we wanted and then stared at us while we ate our meal. She wasn't the only one though, it seemed to be the break area for other servers. Awkward. Not to mention, when asking the size of a burrito (because they have plates w 2 burritos.. never seen that in my life) she looked at my boyfriend and said "what do you think?" And then proceeded to tell him he should get the plate w 2 burritos poking fun at this size. The burritos were normal size, I would be surprised if anyone could eat both. Now onto food. 

**Worst Mexican food I've ever eaten
Let's say everything tasted like it came out of a can. No flavor, sour cream and guacamole smelled rancid and everything with "tomatoes" should really read ketchup. Not to mention the plates are so hot you have to wait a good 5 minutes before anything is tolerable to eat.

**Dinner in the dark
Why would I pay $20 for a plate of Mexican food to eat it in the dark? No thanks.

Needless to say, I will never be coming back to this restaurant. You couldn't pay me to come back.
author: CK F.

description:
This is our favorite place to go for fresh lime margaritas (do not get me started on the Tommy v. Tia margarita argument). Order the Jenny's salad with gambas dressing or anything with gambas dressing. Get a burrito with pollo asada or carne asada or have them as entrees. The best! 

Go to trivia the first Thursday of every month and realize you are not as smart as you think you are...Ger is tough!
author: Mary F.

description:
This place feels old skool. I like old skool. The margarita I ordered was STRONG. I like strong. The wait was not long. I hate long waits. The parking situation sucks here. I hate sucky parking situations. The food came in large quantities and was pretty tasty. I like things in large quantities that are tasty. 

I like it here. For all of the above reasons.
author: Caroline C.

description:
This place has WAY better food than Tommy's Mex. 
Margaritas are solid.
When I rode my bike there the other night (and forgot my lock) they let me park it in a secured patio area outside one of the doors. Very cool. :-)
author: Jason A.

description:
I love Tia Margaritas!  Being a Richmond district native, I've always passed by Tia's but not till recently did I finally dine there.  The margaritas are strong and yummy, and the food is authentic and tasty.  Everything I've ordered, I've totally enjoyed.  

Go for the tasty food, personable staff and strong but delish margaritas.  I always go back for those reasons for sure!
author: Marie B.

description:
Someone told me about this restaurant.You know how good it is and how the drinks are so good(good=strong=kick your ass).

I finally went with a friend,yeah finally and have gone several times after and enjoyed each time.Right on the corner of Clement this place is a decent size and can fill up quickly.

The food was good and the menu offered many choices.

I really like this place and tell other people how I have enjoyed my experience here.

5 stars for service,drinks and decent food.The people who work here have always been nice and professional.

Tasty for real.
author: Dani D.

description:
A good place to grab some Mexican food if your looking for something nicer than a taqueria and want to have a margarita.  The food here is decent, the salsa is excellent, and depending on the waiter - the service can be great.  
The back of the restaurant is dark and kinda quiet, we prefer to sit in the front section where the atmosphere is more lively.
author: Robyn S.

description:
If my aunt made margarita's like this I'd enjoy family reunions more. 

The margaritas are all top shelf and are very tasty. No mixes. Made with fresh squeezed lime juice. For some reason I think things are cooler when made in front of you. 

I'm not a huge fan of their salsa, but I won't complain too much. I do love their flautas, tacos, and quesadillas. Tia Margarita is the funnest lady to watch and talk to.
author: Ali R.

description:
The waitress dwarfed my masculinity. Can somebody please pass my crotch? Tough girl, really. Strolled up, half caressing her guns, legs striding apart with purpose (one couldn't help but wonder what she was packing). 

"What'll it be, boys!"

One never wants to be rude; so incidentally my response wasn't "Not you, baby!" but a more appropriate "...the menu, if you please." Ten minutes later we had a table ensconced with salt-rimmed margaritas; I sipped and said things. To seem interesting I befuddled my crew with tales of the sad decline of intercourse due to boyhood masturbation; evidently a girl blogger in London-town said it was so.  

Food arrived.

Tasty; and no heartburn please, we're irish.
author: Marc M.

description:
My husband did take out last night from TM.  GREAT FOOD.  This is even after the meals traveled a 1 mile distance.  Hubby had the Chile Relleno which he proceeded to scarf along with the warm tortillas, huge side of beans and YUMMY butter rice.  He got me the chicken and beef enchiladas.  Chicken was hand shredded and the beef was ground to a nice texture.  Can't wait to stop by the place for a meal soon.

2 thumbs up Tia Magarita!
author: I have something to say... A.

description: We had  a great time here. The margarita's are fresh and delicious, i left a little buzzed off the double and that is perfect. The food was hot and vibrant with flavor! We will be returning!
author: Jamie K.

description:
I really want to love this place... but the idea of authenticity prevents me from doing so. 

When I look for Mexican dining at a more expensive price, I am usually anticipating an experience that will make me travel through the culture. Instead of a traveling adventure you just get more portions which are really mediocre at best.

Don't get me wrong, for the Richmond District this place can satisfy a craving, but if I had the option of a more authentic mexican food experience this would be the last place I go.
author: Mario G.

description:
The beer at Tia Margaritas was excellent. I had a Tecate in a can, which is one of my all time favorite "get shit faced" beers. 

That's were anything good about Tia Margaritas ends.

If you want some terrible, and I mean terrible food that is dressed up to resemble Mexican food, then TM's is your spot.

If you want some tomato paste/cocktail sauce salsa, then TM's is your spot.

If you want to be the only Mexican in a crowd of Gringos, who think that the food they are eating is authentic, then TM's is your spot.

I have had better "Mexican" food from a Roach Coach parked at the Flea Market and served by Chinese people then I had at TM's.  

You might think I am being harsh, but really, this place is the worst dining experience I have ever had, in regards to food. The server and busser were very nice and attentive. 

Avoid this place. It sucks!
author: Eric B.

description:
Three major things come into my mind when I think of this place.
1) Best shredded beef I've ever tasted - "EVER"
2) Queso con fresco - "YUM" - did somebody say "CHEESE!?"
3) (and this one is most important) CONSISTENCY!!

Any restaurant that can deliver and provide consistency in it's service and cuisine gets 5 stars from me.

Just don't leave without trying a shredded beef taco (or whatever you like), the queso con fresco and leaving a generous tip.  The staff actually care if you enjoy your experience there.

BLESSINGS to this family owned joint and special prayers and condolences to the family for their recent loss of their Mama.  

TIA MARGARITA - YOU ARE LOVED - YOUR TRUE FANS HAVE SPOKEN
author: A H.

description:
Freaking love this place. I come here once a week, and that's only because I don't want to appear overzealous. It's not that the food and drink are the best ever, there's just something about this place that makes you want to be a regular.

The chicken fajita meat is fantastic and used in several of the entree's. Just the right mix of citrus and cumin and some other stuff I can't identify but know it tastes damn good. It's especially yum in the Jenni's Special, which is a salad dish and my jam when I'm trying to feel healthy. Black beans, lettuce, chicken, tiny diced jalapenos, and tons of cheese with some sort of creamy dressing that I never use. Also good are the burritos, ground beef tacos, and steak picado.

Sit at the bar, order a large Margarita - no salt, on the rocks, snack on the chips and tomato-y delicious salsa, order something with fajita meat, and make friends with the bartenders. You'll want to come back every Sunday.
author: Sarah M.

description: Let's be honest this is not the place to come for a "great" home-style Mexican meal (but where in SF can you find that?!?).  What you do find here, in addition to a strong, I repeat a STRONG margarita, is a community.  If there's any place that echoes the nostalgia of the TV show "Cheers" this is it.  Here you will find patrons who've been coming for 10-15, 20+ years and who through this venue have met one another.  I've sat at the bar many of times, met new folks, hear their stories, watch them greet the table near by and others as they walk in the restaurant.  It's a very nice neighborhood / "homey" feeling.  Back to the food, it's not bad at all some dishes better than others.  The chips & salsa are good.  The margaritas are all made from scratch, freshly squeezed limes, tequila, etc. and boy do they poured it strong.  Two double margaritas will set you for the afternoon.
author: Rafael s.

description: Fun place to have dinner with the family on a Friday night! Great atmosphere and energy. Nice bar and yummy top shelf margaritas at a decent price. Food was solid. I really enjoyed their special enchiladas and my 5-year-old asked for seconds on her kids cheese enchilada plate. Husband says his spicy chicken salad was excellent too. I can see us frequenting this place for years to come:)
author: Marcie M.

description:
I love this restaurant.  I probably eat there once a month.  The food is excellent.

THE SERVICE IS SHOTTTTTTTY AS HELL!!!  Out of the 20 or so times I've been there, I can honestly say that the elderly "waitress", who wears glasses and shorter than the other waitress, has f***ed up my order about 14 times.  The shocking thing is that the owners just don't give a crap for some reason.  They must think it's cute that some little old Latino lady (nothing against old people, because it happens to all of us), dresses up in her waitress attire and serves "authentic" Mexican cuisine.  It's not cute.  It's sad.  My friends and I always joke that the ownership hires out of the AARP directory.

Also, make sure you know how to do a little arithmetic, because the bill is - more often than not - WRONG.  This is the only restaurant that makes me triple check my bill.
author: Ash C.

description:
Let me clarify: this place gets 1 star only because I can't give it zero.

Also, if you want my review in short, here it is: Mexican food for Gringos. Service is for those who enjoy watching a four-year-old tie his shoe.


Aside from the hostess practically leaving us in the dust to show us our table, our next first impression was our server asking us for our beverage order, then walking off before we could say anything...the fuck?

He got a margarita, I got a coke. The margarita was your basic margarita, nothing special. The coke was basically soda water with a splash of syrup. I didn't even know you could screw coca-cola up.

The chips were too thick for my taste, and the salsa basically reminded me of Pace Picante. 

After finishing my water with a splash of coke and my actual water, I watched our server pass our table four times before we had to ask a busser for a refill. (Apparently, they also don't do refills on soda, even though their soda comes from the bar, at the well. Cheapskates.) After finally getting her attention, she leaves our table, and elbow checks my boyfriend in the shoulder. We gave her the benefit of the doubt, that she's old and fat and maybe just lost her balance. There's no way she did that on purpose, right? I mean, seriously, right?

The ONLY redeeming quality to the food was that everything was stuffed to the max...his relleno, his taco, my tamale and my enchilada. I fear though that what they splurge on meats, they cut cost in spices-everything was BLAND. Also, the refried beans were sweet (fucking WEIRD), and I'm pretty sure they were using Uncle Ben's rice.

After we watched her screw up the next table's order, we tried asking for our check, eager to leave the stagnant memory of this shithole behind us as soon as possible. Our server motioned to us that she was going to take someone else's order first, then check us out. You bitch.

Sensing our annoyance, she cut them off in the middle of their order to tally our tab, then, when my boyfriend quickly handed her his card, she had the gall to say, "You sure? I mean, I'm human, I make mistakes." Gee, really?

After contemplating what sort of paltry amount we should leave her for a tip (if anything at all), the hostess comes over, shoves his card back in his face, and goes, "We need a new one." Uh, no bitch, what you need is a new fucking attitude.

We left that old lady no tip. If she is in fact the owner, she should put her happy ass back in the office, because as a server, she fucking blows.

I will not be returning to this pathetic excuse for traditional Mexican fare, and I will most definitely be referring people to other places.

I have never been disappointed by Mexican food (unless I go to Chevy's), but I guess there's a first for everything. 

Bottom line: This place is absolutely mediocre, and the only reason people continue to go back is because the only other option for our neighborhood is Tommy's.
author: Sachi T.

description:
I like to try a lot of neighborhood type Mexican restaurants when I get a chance so one day, when I was running some errands on Geary and finished up, we dropped by Tia Margarita to check it out. 

They have their Big Bar in the front and then a pretty cool room in the back.  The arches in the doorways certainly is a nice touch.  

So I've been a few times after that initial visit and they are pretty consistent.  Good food in a nice comfortable setting...
author: Mark W.

description:
Not too impressed.... 

Walked into the bar and Mexican wasn't at all what came to my mind.... Confusion set in.... 

Sat in the corner booth with my friend and chowed down on the chips and salsa.... still not impressed.... 

Ordered fajita platter to share... Flour tortillas were nasty..... had to choke them down with the thick strawberry syrup with ice thing that they called a margarita..... yeah.... 

I won't be going back.... for another unimpressive meal.

P.S. - Do you know what I could have gotten @ my taco truck for 20 bucks???
author: Nora O.

description:
Okay, I admit I am being super generous with the five stars, but for me Tia Margarita is pure comfort food.  It reminds me of the Mexican restaurants we would get to go to growing up in the suburbs of Southern California.  I always get a combination plate and I always get the same thing - enchilada, taco and burrito.  (I have been getting this since I was 10 years old.  :-)  The plates here are huge, so I always end up taking half of it home.

Another reason I give this place five stars is that we always go with our friends that live near there and it's always a treat to see them.  They, like my partner, grew up in the city and this is a place they have gone to for years.  

So, what I am saying is that there are five very personal stars but well deserved.
author: Sean O.

description:
I love this place ! My boyfriend and I are here at least once a week, the waiter knows exactly what we want, we love it!
The food is always consistent, food portion is just right, and service is great...it's definitely nice neighborhood hang out.
author: Ruby L.

description:
I'll have to go back and really pay attention to everything next time so I can write a proper review, but I really liked the place, I have to say. It has a beautifully decorated interior, efficient and polite staff, and good food. My quesadilla was not a huge slab of oily cheese between a limp tortilla, but crispy and melty with really flavorful salsa and guacamole. It came with a salad, rice, and beans. The serving size was just right... this was not a situation of size over quality. However, I saw some other patrons with enormous plates, so I must've chosen from the light-eater's section of the menu, then. They'll keep refilling your chips and salsa, which are actually freshly made.

The margaritas are pretty damn delicious... top shelf, blended... MMMMMGOOD! I don't think I'd get more than one or two drinks per visit, though, or I'd end up broke for the night. Margaritas are sold by the glass (no pitchers) and are about $7 for a single shot and  $10 for a double.

I like this place better than Puerto Allegre. It was busy, but there was plenty of seating and you didn't have to hunt down a waitstaff to take an order. We got our food promptly (and at the same time) and were never rushed to finish up so they could give our table to someone else. I like that Tia Margarita's location isn't on a bustling street... it feels private and cozy... a perfect place to take someone out on a date, to celebrate a birthday, or to just have some drinks with friends.
author: Suzi G.

description:
I've been eating with such a hungry vengeance for the past couple of days that I've half wondered if I have a tater tot in the oven.  Which would be somewhat worrisome if I could stop shoveling food into my mouth long enough to have a bout of serious contemplation.  Although I suppose the fact that it's my womyn/red tent/moon time sort of rules out potential anklebiters for the present.  And also explains why I'm starving.

So, I picked up D from work and was all, "BEANS.  NOW."  All I knew was I needed some big plate of perhaps not wholly authentic Mexican food with some cheesy beans and rice, and luck would have it that we went to Tia Margarita.

Here's the thing about me: I love the real slim shady when it comes to Mexican food, but I also have an abiding love for a tasty semi-whitey approximation of Mexican food.  So naturally I was thrilled to get a taco/enchilada combination with a whole lotta beans and rice on quite possibly the largest plate I've ever eaten on in my life.  As D said, the size of a Toyota Corolla tire.  The enchilada was pretty good if the taco was somewhat lackluster, and D was happy with his scrambled eggs with chorizo.

I had one of their fabled margaritas which I think in multiples would be  happy drunkies in a glass, and the salsa was worthwhile as well: the mild version, if a little too mild for my taste, was still quite good, and I liked that you could taste the flavor of the peppers themselves in the spicy salsa.  It's quite comfy inside Tia Margarita, and as I was trying to figure out what exactly the vibe was, D stopped grazing and pronounced solemnly, "it's like we're not in San Francisco."  Which I don't think was a slam against Tia Margarita or SF - it was a place where we could relax and shovel some good eats into our hungry mouths.
author: Tanya N.

description:
I'm just not feeling very giving with stars tonight..

First of all, parking is a nightmare, but to make it worse, when we finally did get in it took about half an hour to get our orders in, and it wasn't particularly busy.

Food was good, but nothing outstanding. Not sure I'm going back. 

Still searching for decent Mexican West of Van Ness, north of Geary. any ideas?
author: Jason R.

description:
Tia Margarita has it all great food and stiff drinks!  You have the option when you order the Top Shelf Margarita if you want a single or double..double please! The drinks get you effed up! Which is a plus that their chips and salsa are incredible.  Soak up some of the boos.  

I had the Chef's Special which is highly recommended!  Carne Asada, Chicken, 3 Garlic butter prawns, rice, beans and a side of lettuce w salsa.  Huge portion and I didn't have a to go bag, that's how good it was! My partner in crime had the combo fajitas, two thumps up!  

When you leave TM's you will be satisfied and walk a little funny!
author: Frankie F.

description:
I orginally gave this place 4 stars (see the reasons below) but after going a few times I've downgraded...because:

1. I kept getting this really slow & mean waitress
2. I decide the food wasn't as good as I originally thought. I liked it a lot at first and then kinda OD'd on Chimichangas since I missed that EAst coast crap so much.  I just can't get away from Tortilla Heights. It's so close to home and i like thier salsa better. 

Because this is exactly what i was looking for! 

70s/80s style americanized mexican food. Big plates, beans, rice, chips and salsa at your table. and YUMMMY margaritas.

PLUS the food is pretty darn good. We pigged out .

We tried these empanadas with egg and chili and cheese in them. AWESOME. the guac was also very good. 

the chips weren't the best..but the salsa was stellar.

Our entrees were both  hcombo plates and there was plenty to take home to munch on. 

Great prices,  friendly service..and a cool atmosphere. If you want a place that reminds you of eating mexican out as a kid (if you grew up outside of california i guess) then this is your place. 

they have good food..but it's not california taqueria style and i'm happy to have a change of pace!! 

I'll be back!!
author: Amy J.

description:
I think Tia served us on Sunday. 

Well, Tia muy Loca sure did. Our waitress, although I'm sure really nice, was kind of all over the place. When she asked me what I wanted, I said "enchiladas." 5 seconds go by of her staring at me, so I repeat "the enchiladas, please," thinking that I must mumble.

(Side note: why can't a single person at a coffee shop spell my name correctly when they ask for it? I'm always Jerry. I HATE the name Jerry.)

(Side note #2: Jerrys of the world... please don't take offense; it's just not my name)

Tia muy Loca then continues to stare at me for 10 seconds. No joke; it was one of those moments where I started to get a nervous grin, like "is this really happening?" and my friends started giggling because they were just as confused. Finally, she speaks: Chicken or beef?

YES. Mission accomplished. 

Mind you, there was no language barrier at play. My friends had ordered right before me with ease. Later she joked with me about understanding me... but as if it was my fault, not hers. Hmm, Tia, not so sure about that.

Anyway, the food was pretty good and one of the other servers/bus boys was EXTREMELY cool and friendly. He made sure we were always stocked with chips and hot salsa, hooked my friend up with a free soda and shook our hands when we left. Why must I be such a sucker for good/genuine customer service?

I will definitely come here again. Partly because it's so close, but partly because I want to see what my next adventure brings.
author: Jared S.

description: Loved it!! I went here with my family for my birthday. The atmosphere was lively and our waitress, the young Irish woman, was amazing! The margarita's were mixed well. I got the strawberry one just because I am not a big fan of sour stuff. The food was really good. Pretty big portions for the price. The only thing is that if you want authentic Mexican food this is not the place for you. The food is more like Tex-Mex, think Chevys.  All in all I would definitively go there again.
author: cecilia a.

description:
Indeed it is not authentic Mexican food, but frankly very little of the places in SF are authentic (startle!)...even in the Mission.  Many SF hipsters are apparently expert identifiers of culturally authentic cuisine (it's the SMUG, you can't blame them).  If you are actually from Mexico, there are pray few places in this city where you get the real deal.  Tia's (a-duh!) ain't one of em.  Was it the sports bar look that fooled you?    

That being said, it's mostly good Margaritas and Americanized-Californiazed (whatever the hell that means) comfort food.  For Christ's sake they have Taquitos like out of the oven.  and another downside is the tv only play sports, but you can tune that out.
