Come here on a weeknight after a shitty day at work with a good friend.  Come around 8pm (the screaming food-throwing crotchfruit are gone then).  Grab a Margarita and a beer as a chaser, order some comfort food, and if you are an SF overgroomed metrosexual food-rater attempting to judge a restaurant strictly along cultural guidelines, there's this country just south of here called Mexico, where you can get a great, culturally idiosyncratic burrito.
author: betty b.

description:
Most expensive mexican food ever.  we came here with intentions to eat, but a $12 burrito was just not what we were looking for.  So instead we drank liquor and walked around the corner to gordos.

I do have to say that the food did look pretty good...just way too spensive for poor people like me.
author: desiree n.

description:
Food: Anything w/ Shrimp/Prawns is tops in city.  (I.e., if it says "Gambas", get it)
Drinks: Margaritas here second to no one in SF.
Crowd: Local Richmonders and surprising number of folks driving over from other hoods.
Vibe: Lively, great energy, relaxed
Service: family run and seemingly onsite and available at all times

This food and atmosphere at Tia's is contemporary, but the place also somehow keeps a solid throwback vibe to a time where families ran restaurants and you could go there for generations: where you feel totally at home and where food + service + margaritas are all top shelf.  

Tia's has probably the best mexican dishes featuring gambas in the city.  If you've ever been to a coastal town in Mexico and been blown away by fresh seafood incorporated into a dish, then you'll feel like you're back on vacation.  Everything else is solid as well.  

I probably don't have to shout out the margaritas, but they blow away just about everywhere else in the city.  Even with Tres Agaves developing a thousand types of margaritas at every price point, there's not much to really innovate on Tia's classic margaritas. 

Finally, service at this place definitely feels like it's a family run restaurant.  From what I can tell in going there, there's always an owner on site.  If anyone has ever had a problem with service here, I'd suggest just asking for the manager because you're going to get real support directly from the owner/family within 2 minutes.  There's no other place where I can get street parking easy enough, super Mexican food and have that atmosphere.  

Also... VERY GOOD FOR GROUPS.  If you've got 10+ friends that need a place to meet up asap, Tia's is pretty big and is often my best bet.  Plus, groups + margaritas goes very well.
author: Ken M.

description:
We were in the mood for margaritas but wanted to go beyond our standards (Tommy's & Tortilla Heights). Tia Margarita features one of the worst margaritas I've ever had. First, it took a while for the bartender to get to us (one of my pet peeves is non-acknowledgement. I'll wait patiently as long as you acknowledge me). When he finally took our order, it was made with Jose--yuck. I ordered the top shelf for round 2--still gross. 

Our guacamole came out of a food processor or blender. Our appetizer sampler was pretty good. The host/waiter was very nice...but in the future, I'm sticking to Tommy's or Tortilla Heights when I'm in the mood for a good margarita.
author: L N.

description: Tia Margarita would score better but for a single flaw; the horrible rude service.  We recently moved in to the neighborhood and have visited Tia Margarita on five occasions and eaten there three times, the two times we left were a direct result of of the off-putting hostess.  At a recent visit we tried to pass out 25 minute wait by ordering an over-priced crappy margarita from the bar, but never managed to catch the clique-ish bartenders' eye. Needless to say we went over to Bluefin Sushi for a pleasant meal. When I have eaten here the food is great, the older waitress is sweet, some of the others are a little inept.  The ambiance is old-school, with a dark and roomy dining room, which I like.  Tia Margarita, I want to love you, but you just won't let me.
author: Stuart H.

description:
Tommy what??!?!   This is the place to go if your out in the avenues.

Went to a party last night and a bunch of us ended up here for food and more drinks.  The food and drinks were great and the service was top notch.  Our server and bartender have probably worked there since the place opened and made our party feel like we had been coming there since the place opened.  I haven't felt like that on the west coast in a very long time...it was great...
author: k. w.

description:
Tia Margaritas- when you dont have _time_ to wait for a buzz. Seriously the best margaritas in town- both in taste, and in drunk-ification. How the hell can something so tasty get you so wrecked so quick? Who cares, I loves every sip!

Fortunately, the portion sizes at this place were set by Andre the giant bigger brother, so not only will you not go hungry but your unborn children and that african kid you give less than the cost of a cup of coffee to support - will be eating the leftovers for years. The food is damn good too- and the salsa's are ridiculously yummy. Thank god its not in my neighborhood- otherwise my name would go from 
"guapo" to "gordo" in two shakes of a pinata. Damn skippy.
author: Tim V.

description:
This place was fine. 
Service was good (though the Irish accent definitely threw me off)
Ambiance is...nothing special
The food is solid if not too exciting; your stereotypical 'American Mexican'. The portions were pretty monstrous.  The salsa rojo left a little to be desired, but the salsa verde was good.
Prices were reasonable considering; ~13-15/entree
author: Aaron D.

description:
I'd give the food 3*s and the service 5*s, purely for its ridiculousness and authenticity.  I think Tia herself was serving us and she was a total hoot.  She may or may not have been coming on to me, but either way it made for a genuinely fun experience.  

The margaritas seem small for the price (no match for Tommy's) and the food is nothing special, but for an instant 8PM seating of a group of 8 it's tough to beat.
author: Matt S.

description:
Youre not kidding about the parking! It does suck! Luckily I lived on 23rd Ave and walked to Tia Margaritas...

The margaritas are tasty & strong, handmade with precision and a lil bit o love AND among the best Ive ever had (besides Tommys on Geary)! Easy as shit to make! Fresh lime juice, Triple Sec and Sauza Commemorativo... Get the large glass and youll be doing yourself a favor ($7-8 bucks)!

Why cant I find the same type margarita in LA? PLEASE HELP! Everybody uses that shitty pre-made mix or its already pre-made and shot straight out of the soda gun... BOOOO! You know who you are and you should be ashamed to call yourself a mexican restaurant! Put some elbow grease into it for cryin out loud!

Hey, its a festive bar! The food is pretty good, but you just need to stick with the margs!

Caddy corner to Tia is Prime Time Sports Bar. Have a beer, watch the Giants and say hello to Joe for me!
author: Bryan F.

description: Tia Margarita's looks inviting from the street. The name for one has "margarita" in it.... We finally tried this place out last weekend and were a little disappointed. The inside of the building looks like a strange mobster-mom's diner type atmosphere and smells exactly like it looks. Dreary... The salsa was horrible (they give you two and both are bland), the waitress was an older lady that scolded us for ordering margarita's since we had "faces like babies". Despite all this negativity when the margarita's arrived they were delicious and much appreciated! They helped us get through the food, the 50's diner music and the disapproving grandma of a waitress.
author: Holly P.

description: I've eaten here a few times in the distant past. For me this place and Tommy's are interchangeable. Food is old school. Pasty textures. Bland flavors. Menu populated with typical Tex-Mex style tacos, burritos, enchiladas. If I'm in the mood for good Mexican cuisine, I'm gonn'a travel to the Mission to get more authentic food that tastes better.
author: Tom S.

description:
I am ashamed to admit that before going to Tia Margarita I had never been to a Mexican Restaurant. Sure, I had been to Taqueria's and places like Chili's but we all know those are not real Mexican restaurants. Tia Margarita, then, is where I lost my Mexican restaurant virginity.

Like losing my real virginity, afterwards I said to myself "I should have done this a lot sooner."

The food is delicious, portions substantial and prices reasonable. Oddly enough the style and presentation of the food reminded me of the large family gatherings from my childhood though I'm not sure why (but that familiarity is a good thing.) The only downside is the acoustics of the building reverberate, making it potentially loud and difficult to converse.

Despite the extreme distance from my apartment, this is a place I would gladly return to.
author: Keith M.

description:
I thought people were kidding when they told me they found good Mexican food in the Inner Richmond.... little did I know I was in for a real treat here. 

Everything from the chips and salsa, to the giant serving of pollo asada, to the tasty chicken fajitas, to the knock-your-socks-off top shelf double margaritas gets 5 stars. 

I find it funny that I live in a city with so much good food to choose from, and when my friends and I get together for a fun night out... where do we choose to go? None other than Tia Margarita.
author: Kate Y.

description:
As a disclaimer, Tia Margarita did have wonderful chips and salsa (red salsa is bomb), and the portions were huge. 

One thing that really bums me out about San Francisco, is the lack of Mexican restaurants. I'm not talking about taquerias. I'm talking about actual Mexican restaurants. Then the ones that are here such as Tia Margarita, are mediocre. 

So I ordered a single Margarita and it tasted like pure tequila. I asked if they could make it less strong and the waitress brought out this sweet and sour mix which then made it WAY too sweet. So I ended up just not drinking it. 

The food was OK but portions were huge. I got the 3 item combo with the Chile Rellano, Burrito and taco. The best part about it was the Burrito. My boyfriend got the chicken tostada. That was much better than my combo. The Spanish rice was just eh. 

Overall, prices are reasonable for the huge portions but the food just isn't that great. Oh how I long for San Diego Mexican food...
author: Rachel S.

description: I can't speak for the margaritas, but stay away from the food here. Yikes.
author: J T.

description:
This place makes me nostalgic for the Mexican places I went to as a kid living in the 'burbs of LA.  Is it "real" Mexican food?  No, but ultimately who cares?  Food is food, and the only thing that should matter is how it tastes.  I could stay on this soapbox for a lot longer but that wouldn't be very useful or funny (and only somewhat cool) so I digress.

The requisite chips come with 2 kinds of salsa, one spicy, the other somewhat spicy, both delicious.   Most of the entrees are, to quote a friend, "bigger than the size of your head," but if you're a nibbler like me, there are smaller versions that are plenty big enough and you'll still probably take some home with you.  The margaritas so good that after about a decade of not drinking tequila ("Jose C." and I had an argument one night in college), I tried one of these and I've been born again, saved, glory hallelujah - not by Jose, but he has a few nicer, friendlier cousins.  

I've been here 3 times now with 3 different people, and no complaints.  A little pricey, but alternatively you can always just split an appetizer and munch on the chips instead while drinking a margarita (or two or three).
author: Sus... B.

description:
"If it's not Scottish it's crap!" Well in this case that applies to Tia Margarita's margaritas. They may as well have been Scotch! I had one and it tasted horrid. For some reason I had nightmares of hobbit's feet for a week after drinking that Margy. I quickly switched to cerveza to accompany the meal. Normally I wouldn't be so dang harsh about it, but if it's in yer freakin' name, HELLO! best get it right peoples. 

Food's not bad. Tommy's on Geary has better 'ritas. Zuni's are totally splendid!!
author: Johnny C.

description:
This is my new favorite Mexican place, and not just because it is also the closest to home.

I had chicken fajitas.  My friend had a combination with a crispy unsoggy taco and a burrito.

It's tough to differentiate yourself in the Mexican food industry of San Francisco.  It mostly comes down to the chips and salsa.  This place's are tops.  

The waitress was very cool and friendly too.  I'm going back soon.
author: Dan C.

description:
I joined some friends at this place on Friday night and although it is no fault of Tia Margarita necessarily, parking is ridiculous.  We might have been searching for 30 minutes.  Anyways the fajitas I had were pretty good and the margarita I had was very good, but the service overall lagged a bit.  No refill on the waters after our food came out.  And all 3 of us soon had empty glasses and were apparently out of luck.  

I don't see myself going back anytime soon, especially not on a weekend.  Few places are worth the parking headache that hampers this restaurant.
author: Tom K.

description:
Best margaritas I have ever had!!!

Sometimes I will go to Tia Margarita's just to get a couple double margaritas on the rocks with salt....yumm, it is making my mouth water just thinking about these sweet concoctions.  The secret is they use REAL limes.  

Their food is awesome too.  You get these huge plates of food.  I can hardly ever finish my meal, which is good because then I get to take home left-overs for the next day!

The only downside, is that it sometimes gets crowded and it is hard to get a space at the bar.  oh, and parking is sometimes, well I should say is always difficult.  But hey sometimes you have to suffer through a little parking troubles and a little wait to get some awesome margaritas and food!
author: kim l.

description: After hearing rave reviews from some of my best friends of whom I thought I trusted with some basic rad-Mexican-food identifying qualities, I finally tried Tia about a week ago.  Major plus: the margaritas. Straight and to the point, just like I like 'em!  Everything else, from the bland, greasy, unsalted chips, to the boring red salsa, to the ick enchilada plate -- I seriously do not know what they are thinking.  Friendships are based on trust, and I am seriously re-evaluating these relationships.  If you can't ID mediocre-at-best Mex food, then what are you good for?
author: e w.

description:
A friend brought me here.  Her boyfriend used to come here as a youngster and still does, till this day.

I ate my belly full of their Guatemalan Tostada -- yummm!  Oh, and did I mention that they make their margarita's super stiff?

Three stars!
author: Mennlay A.

description: I love this place.  Other than really crappy parking I always enjoy eating here.  Honestly there may be other places that have better burritos or soups or whatever, but in San Francisco most all of those places are hole in the wall spots where you stand in line get your burrito and leave.  If you want a nice hot plate of enchiladas with beans, rice, melted cheese with a never ending stream of chips and delicious salsa then this is a place you need to try.  I recommend the Enchiladas with sour cream sauce with a fried egg on top.
author: Robert S.

description:
The food here is ok. The servings are huge! 

Too bad they stopped doing Irish Pub Trivia!
author: Kevo M.

description:
I ended up here after one day we were driving around liek crazy trying to find parking. After awhile a friend suggested Tia Margarita's and I was like... "wow... good margarita..." Then there were the chips and salsa... "oooohhh.. two kinds of salsa... yummy!". Then I decided to go all out and order a combo (2 items) dish and when it came I was like... "Woah Nelly.... I won't have room for my Margarita!!!!"... but no worries... I polished that right away.  I enjoyed the food and have been coming back for more for a few years now. Thanks to Tommy's for being over crowded and bad parking! 

The shrimp here is EXCELLENT! 4 thumbs up if I had two to spare!
author: Amelia M.

description:
Oh my, I love the Carne Asada burritos here.  Usually get that with re fried beans.  The price difference for a single burrito and a double burrito plate is $2, so I usually just go for the latter and bring one home.  These burritos are pretty big, so you probably won't finish both in one sitting unless you're a fatty like my friend Frank (see my friends list).

History:  I used to pretty much live right across the street from this place.  Didn't start coming here until about 6 months before I left (Isn't that how it always is?).

I only like coming here at night.  The place has a different atmosphere during the day.  Parking sucks in this area.  Ok bye.
author: Casey F.

description:
I randomly walked in with a couple of friends on a Saturday and made it to a table just before the crowds of people came in. I'm not one to dis-credit other people's tast in food, but some of the reviews have me wondering if their taste buds are in working order. 

Tia Margarita's classic margarita is probably the worst I've had. Their food was bland and super Americanized. I ordered a tostado salad which was piled about four inches high with iceberg lettuce and had a hard time locating the soggy tortilla that I can only assume was crispy b/c there was no evidence of crispness by the time it got to my table. My friends dishes were equally bland and were not worth the price they paid for it. I live only a few blocks away, but I will certainly steer clear from now on. Taco trucks are about a bizillion times better than this place.
author: Lindsey G.

description:
I really wanted to like this place when my husband and I dined here on Friday night.  We walked in and the place was packed, and we stood at the door hoping that someone would at least acknowledged us, but after about 3 minutes, we decided to walk towards the back and try to seat ourselves. This is when we saw the lady(not very friendly) and we said 2 for dinner, and she said this way, and we hurried behind her to this dark dining room. I am not a fan of dark dining rooms. I love to be able to see outside, or at least see some day light. 

Being a vegetarian, it was difficult to find an item on the menu, so  I opted for the veggie enchilada which was basically cheese and and a salad on the side. The food was very bland. It lacked the flavors that I am used to having when I go to other Mexican restaurants. Having lived int the Richmond District for many years, we've always dined at Tommy's and really loved it. My husband ordered the chicken Tacos combination, and he said his was bland as well. I tried the rice and the beans and once again no big flavors.  The service was excellent once we were seated even though they were crowded. 

I am not sure if we will be going back to Tia's any time soon.  The three stars is for the service. I'd probably give the food a 1 or 2 stars, and the lady that took us to our table a 1 star.
author: Arlene D.

description:
Being an LA transplant, sometimes I just crave those hole in the wall family owned mexican restaurants I go to every time i'm back in LA. NOw this may not be a hole in the wall, but definitely fulfills my desire for for tasty, sit down mexican food. WHen the taquerias just won't do it, tia margarita saves the day!

any one of the chef's specials is bound to be more food than you can handle, delicious margaritas, which may not have the same variety as tommy's mexican, the food is undeniably better than tommy's!!!

would of been a 5-star rating, if it wasn't for the same old, senile waitress we get EACH and EVERY time, yet, i still come back! I guess that's the only problem with family owned joints, you can't fire your aunt!
author: Eric O.

description: Hell yes! January '11 I moved out here from Seattle and I couldn't find a single place in the city that could compare to the Mexican food up there. This place does. Amazing food with giant portions and a full bar. Drinks seem to take a while if you sit at a booth. The bar actually takes up more room than the restaurant. The people there were nice, even if the company I was with didn't seem to think so but they were blaming out waiter for our drinks coming in the middle of our meal. I was just tearing away at my super burrito and didn't give a shiz.
author: Chris I.

description:
The food is good, the service is horrible if you have to deal with the female owner.  She's very moody, self-righteous, & mean.

My husband has been eating there since he was a kid with his grandma and I've been enjoying the food for the last 3 years but we no longer go since we don't enjoy abuse with our dinner.
author: S. C.

description:
Yummy with a punch margaritas.. Get the large its the only way to do it! Bartenders nice, especially the girl with the long black hair.

Food reasonably priced entrees with huge portions. Have got to love the un-limited access to the *FREE* chips and spicy salsa. Oh yes!

Can get extremely busy on weekends, so come early. Plus, every time I've been lately it seems they are always closed, so minus a 1/2 star for that :p

My vote is in 31/2 stars Tia Margarita.
author: Kelli H.

description: Strike Three ... We were outta there. We live in the neighborhood and decided to give Tia M. one last try after bad experiences on two previous visits. No such luck. I can accept so-so food in a local place if the employees are friendly and the service is good, but those two attributes are in short supply here.  I'm sure they have some nice people on staff besides the two we have encountered. This time we were treated by the hostess to a masterfully subtle blend of rudeness and indifference in our polite attempts to be seated in the bar area with five empty tables, only one of which was reserved. Instead, we were ushered to the bowels of the restaurant and literally ignored after we showed the slightest hint of reluctance to follow. We left after it was apparent that we had become invisible to her; all within the span of about four minutes. I should have recognized that our disappointment was in the cards: it's never a good indicator when the hostess barely masks her irritation as she hoists herself out of her seat (at the bar!) in order to condescend to inconvenient customers hoping to be seated. There must be some super-secret inner circle of happy locals along with a few wayward innocents that manage to give this place enough business to keep it afloat. The second star is because the bar area actually seems like it could be okay for a drink and some chips.
author: Dave E.

description:
I don't think you'd want to get the food here because it is kinda Anglo but the decor is fun and the servings are huge and the Margarita is solid. Humm...guess it's held its own. Maybe the owners own the building and don't have to worry about a lease.

Just hope they get an updated Chef-arino por favore.
author: miriam b.

description: I am giving Tia Margarita 5 stars because I love coming here.  Yes, I have had better Mexican food.  Yes, I have had better chips and salsa.  Yes, I have had better service.  It deserves 5 stars because dining at Tia Margarita is a singular experience.  The restaurant décor is festive. The bar up front is teaming with people and provides the perfect opportunity for prime people watching.  The crowd ranges from 20-somethings to 60-somethings so there is zero "scene".  You can roll into the restaurant with a jeans and t-shirt or high heels.  Don't come expecting sustainably-grown artisan salsas, little trios of marinated steak tacos arranged dutifully on colorful rectangular plates or an artfully constructed wine list.  It's just one big melting pot of people in search of a big plate of Mexican food, maybe a few good margaritas and a lively atmosphere.
author: Holly L.

description: Margarita's here were amazing.  I think we specifically traveled there for the drinks and enjoyed some chips and salsa.
author: Jessica R.

description:
We were craving Mexican food, and picked this area on a random inclination. We opted for this over the better reviewed Tommy's due to the fact that Tia's actually lists their prices online (who doesn't do that?).

In terms of this place it was... okay. It tends to favor quantity over quality, which might appeal to someone that is super hungry... but we tend to prefer it in reverse order. The portions here are very big though, especially for the price. A single entry was more than enough to keep this couple filled, while the chips and salsa kept coming before hand (without us having to ask for it, which was a plus).

The downside was the food itself. To be fair, the female component of this review team is very tough when it comes to Mexican food (a byproduct of a parent who cooks yummy Mexican dishes), so lacking food of the Mexican variety tends to be less tolerated. On the night we went, we ordered the large platter with three different options so as best to sample everything. We got the burrito, the relleno, and the enchilada. The burrito was... okay. The chicken inside wasn't great. but it was huge with a lot of spices. The Relleno was a little lacking though. We tend to associate rellenos as being very flavorful, and this in all honesty was one of the duller tasting ones we have had. The weakest part of the meal was the enchilada. It tasted kind of the like the ones you would find in a TV dinner... not in terms of being reheated, but the ingredients tasted identical. Oh, also we were distraught with the rice, which was simply buttery instead of Spanish.

Overall, the place probably deserves a 2.5, as we have been to far worse locations that have been given a two, but its not quite high enough to earn that three.
author: Sami R.

description:
I love real Mexican food. It should come from a dirty taqueria or a truck, not a sit down restaurant with a waitstaff. Burritos should be served right off the grill wrapped in foil for $5, not served on a plate with a knife and fork for $15. Mexican food is honest, and should be served as such. 

These are the reasons why I choose to never go to any sit down Mexican restaurants. But, keeping an open mind and trying new things are my forte, and I was pleasantly surprised when I was introduced to Tia Margarita.

My first thought was, "Great, another mediocre Mexican restaurant with overpriced burritos on a plate. They better have good margaritas!" The margaritas are made by hand with fresh ingredients, very good. VERY GOOD chimichanga, pretty good enchiladas, good chips and salsa. 

I'd probably only go back if a friend wanted to go there, because I like my food cheap, good, and honest, and you get that from places with a sizzling grill right next to a ringing cash register right next to a big jar of horchata right next to a sticky table top. Check out my full review on my blog, see profile.
author: Gene M.

description:
Sooooo amazing and suchhhhhh a great deal! You don't have to travel to the Mission or go as far as San Diego for some authentic Mexican food. Not diet friendly! One meal can easily suffice as two especially after diving into refillable chips and salsa. They usually provide you with two types of salsa and don't distinguish between the two, so spicy sensitive peeps be careful! 

To start I would try the shrimp and garlic. Since I discovered my aversion to garlic I haven't tried it again since but from what I remember it was de-lish! Plump shrimp with fresh garlic. 

Now the key to making two meals out of one is to order the 3 item combo plate for a couple bucks more. I usually have a burrito, taco and enchilada. The enchiladas are in a true Mexican red sauce and are oozing with cheese. The burrito: hot damn it is one HUGE burrito! That's where the idea of "two meals" comes in: eat the taco and enchilada (or any other combo) and then save the burrito for another time. Its even more delightful the next day! 

Margaritas are STRONG which often leads to a good time. I'm always groaning from a food baby when I leave this place but am so so so happy :)
author: Heather S.

description: The service sucks. We were kicked out of a table because we were only having drinks and appetizers. The server wasn't friendly and we were literally pushed out of our table because we were not ordering off the dinner menu. I would not come back here again. They didn't even prepare anything special for cinco de mayo. What a shame. I'm glad they gave us a reason to leave, we found a friendlier establishment down the street.
author: Jason D.

description: I really liked this place.  They don't make places like this anymore.  I like it better than, dare I say, Tommy's.  Granted I went earlier in the evening for dinner but it was still quiet but not completely empty and we could all hear each other.  The food is good and if you share, it's plenty of food and a good deal.  We ended up getting two shot margaritas and holy moly, it put some hair on my chest.  All in all, this would be a fantastic place for a larger group.
author: Kirsten M.

description: I don't know if you've ever gone on a chile relleno hunt, but I have, and I can honestly say that Tia's has a dreamy chile relleno. I could do without the rice pilaf and sitting at a booth around the bar, and the salsa is just a complete Elm Street Nightmare. And although I can somewhat appreciate the ethnic beauty of their two giant gold masks (are their eyes open or closed?), I have to admit that they kind of frighten me. But! -- they serve ginger ale (which I adore!) and it's hard to complain too much when the staff is so friendly. Right? Right.
author: Natasha P.

description:
Fabulous Mexican locals haunt!!

I really wish I could write an in-depth review on Tia; however, I was slightly under the influence ... Slightly, okay.?...  Well, maybe slightly under the influence when I walked in ... By the time we left -- we were downright drunk.  What??  I know.  I know.  I make my parents proud.  I really do.

Drinkies:
What I can tell you is that the bartenders ROCK!  Granted one of my girlfriends has been going to Tia since she moved into the neighborhood 7 years ago - she's a regular.  They serve up potent margaritas... Potent!!

Food:
We ordered the chicken fajitas (with *no* oil per Moi ... I like to make it difficult) - YUMMY!  Again, maybe we were a bit easier to please due to our slightly intoxicated state ... But I do recall these being tasty!

So, considering my state of mind, if I do say so myself, the review should give you exactly what you want ... ;)
author: Nicole Rynee B.

description:
i'm a whiskey gal, but i don't mind indulging in a margarita from here.  they don't saturate the alcohol w/sweet and sour mix, and mainly use fresh lime juice in their margaritas.  i prefer to have mine on the rocks.  

never mind what everyone else ordered, my shrimp enchiladas where insanely delicious.  they don't skimp on the shrimp portions like many restaurants do, and the way they cook the shrimp is just divine.

our server was not consistent w/her prices.  shrimp is an additional cost, but she kept up-ing the price when we asked about different dishes which we wanted to add shrimp to. at one stage she said it was $17 for a shrimp quesadilla appetizer.  we thought that was absurd.   she also didn't seem to hear things we requested.  in fairness she was in her golden years, and you could see the relief on her face when she sat down at the end of her shift.
author: Sheri N.

description:
I love this joint!
Is it even possible to eat this much food in one sitting? Don't even answer, I know you can't do it. Even in your Thanksgiving elastic maternity sweats it's just too much food, on a giant plate to take down in one sitting you just can't. so stop... 
But therein lies the beauty, leftovers for the 4am hungover/still drunk stumble to the kitchen. Just picture it, you're starving and feel awful... (check the clock, dear god please don't let it be time to get up for work yet) No! it's only 4am! YES! 2.5 more hours of coma to go before the nasty alarm goes off. 
Open the fridge (blinded momentarily by the 40 Watt bulb) then you see it, the non-biodegradable Styrofoam box inside of the non-biodegradable plastic bag, and it hits you... the leftover burrito from dinner! God damn does it get any better? Really... does it?  Help me....
author: matt l.

description: Great place. Food is traditional, margaritas are better than Tommy's. All locals eat here.
author: Swissie M.

description:
Excellent waiter/bartender service. Quite friendly.

Chips & Salsa to start. Love the salsa!

Had to start with some margaritas. Excellently blended. Loved it!

Quesadilla & Burritos. Food was not bad, but it just doesn't feel the same when you don't eat with your hands.
I was about to dig in with my hands but everyone else in the place were using the forks and knives. Didn't want to act like a savage, so I refrained.

Overall, it was a good experience. I guess I still prefer the taquerias.
author: Jimmy N.

description:
Finally a decent place to get good mexican food AND good margaritas in SF for a reasonable price. We stumbled into this place after driving by Pizzetta 211 and seeing it was too packed. Having sworn off trying mexican food in SF after too many disappointing experiences, did I really want to give this place a chance?

I was a little hung over from the night before, and a good mexican dinner with a couple strong, tasty margaritas would really hit the spot so I thought...lets go for it.

From the moment the chips and salsa hit the table, I was sold. We got fresh, warm chips salted perfectly with 2 types of salsa which were very good. I got a 3 item combo, with excellent tasting beans. ( I typically judge a mexican place off its beans, chips, and guac, then the crispy taco, flavor of enchilada sauce, and tortilla quality) All of these things ranged from pretty good to excellent. 

From now on, this is our place when I feel like gorging myself on mexican food and margaritas. It is worth the trip....which actually wasnt too bad from Noe. Plus there is a parking lot right around the corner which only charges $1 per hour. I fundamentally have an issue paying $10 for parking on $12 mexican combo plates so the parking situation coupled with everything else makes this place ideal.
author: susan c.

description:
This place remains a mystery to me. Aside from the availability of margaritas served by friendly bartenders, this restaurant traffics in one thing and one thing only: poor food that's overpriced. 

This isn't Mexican food. It isn't a fresh American take on Mexican food. This is the food you have at your friend's house when you sleep over in elementary school, and you are faced at the dinner table with a bunch of cheese, overcooked meats, undistinguished tortillas, and generic sauces piled high.

Understand, it is a fun spot -- its facade makes the street corner lively, and the front bar section is always active. But the food itself is so substandard, especially in a city with this much good Latin American eats to choose from, you have to wonder how it doesn't only stay in business, but appears to thrive.

Richmond District Mexican is pretty limited. The two Gordos (on Geary and, oddly nearby, on Clement) are dependable but routine. Pancho's (on Geary, near Mel's) tries a little harder, but can't seem to decide whether to commit to Fresh or to Mex. Chino's (on Balboa, out toward the ocean) is pretty darn sloppy. Tommy's is the best of the batch (the specialty dishes are pretty good, the rest generic but dependable), but its bar is far more easily packed (and, thus, uncomfortable) than is Tia's. Maybe Tia just does well as the perceived greater of six lessers? 

Having pondered this for, literally, a decade, I've come to the following conclusion. My theory is it's a combination of alcohol and families. Half the folks are drinking so many of those sweet margaritas that they're not even paying attention to the food, and half the folks are happy to find a place with food bland-but-different enough that young kids will eat it without complaining. I guess that makes Tia the TGIF of the Richmond District.
author: OuterLands X.

description: We love this place. The review below is nasty. Ignore them :D
author: sharon g.

description:
I like it in here - from the outside you can't tell what it's like inside, but once you enter the vortex - it's all good.

I felt perfectly comfortable snogging away at  my drinky solo at the bar and had wonderful food and chats with friendly neighbors while I was at it.

After a couple margaritas, I'm just glad I was walking home!
author: Sue U.

description:
For the following reasons:

1) Double Margaritas on the rocks. Two of these no-nonsense, never-weak gems and my night is made. Best I've ever had.  

2) Salsas - full of flavor, I get a perfect mix with half hot-half mild salsa. Last time I was there, the bartender gave me a habenero-lemon-salt salsa. It was excellent, lots of heat and lots of zing. 

3) Chefs platter. For 16 bucks, you get carne asada, gambas in garlic-butter, and BBQ pollo. The gambas is the best I've ever had, but the carne, although tender could use a little more marinade. 

One downside. If you go later, the service in the restaurant becomes non-existent about 30 minutes before closing, and any further service is rushed and sparse in order to get you out. This has happened to me several times, and is the reason the place did not get 5 starts.
author: Yaj ..

description:
I wasn't expecting much when I heard about a mexican restaurant way out in the Richmond on Clement St.  It seems as though I was right.  The food was mediocre, par for a cheap mexican joint off the beaten path.  Nothing special:fajitas, enchiladas, rellenos, etc.  Obviously people don't go there for the food.  It's for the drinks.  
     The bar was littered with sloppy drunk old dudes... at 7pm on a Tuesday!!!!!  It must be the local drunk hangout.  I'm all for establishing a local watering hole.  But I am also for cutting off stumbling drunk idiots yelling at the top of their lungs in a family restaurant.  What's worse is you have to walk past the sea of drunk to get to the host stand, where they ignore you for about five minutes  while the employees gossip.  Where is the host you ask?  Why, she is basking in the attention she is getting from the slobs as they all stand around her with their tongues hanging out of their mouthes.  
     While the slobs at the bar guzzled down their drinks one after another, (getting louder and stupider in an already confined space), we waited 15 mins for 2 bottled beers.  The service?  Pretty sucky.  The staff was all too willing to sit down and shoot the shit with the regulars while completely ignoring everyone else.  Maybe our food took 40 minutes because it was sitting under the heat lamp while the staff jerked off.
    Any restaurant where the staff sits down with their friends in the middle of dinner rush is not an establishment I care to visit again.  You would need the best, cheepest food and drinks in the world to get me to put up with that sad excuse for service.
author: Tyler J.

description:
Why is it that in a great city of San Francisco so few places serve margaritas and those that do stray away from the traditional recipe of agave, tequila and lime?  Not Tias!

The food is solid and the drinks are terrific but most of all it is a great environment to watch a game while munching on some chips and salsa.
author: p a.

description: What a gem! Stumbled across this place one night after an afternoon at land's end. The margaritas are strong and yummy and the food is huge and delicious. I just wish it was more convenient! I rarely end up that far out on Clement, but when I do it's a treat.
author: Lauren B.

description:
Not too shabby.  The food here isn't gonna shoot you in to a Mexican orgasm, but those calling it bland American food have never eaten at a Chi-Chi's.  The chips and mild salsa are a great start.  Usually I like hot, but the hot salsa here will leave you hurting.

I went Enchiladas Verde and found it was fine, but really the ample sour cream smothered on top is what saved it.  Black beans are cool, rice is salty, and lettuce/salsa thing is kinda strange.  Good margaritas and service was super, although there were not many there on a Sunday night.

I'd go back for the drinks, chip, and some of the food, so would recommend the bar side of things.
author: John H.

description:
Tia, you should really consider canning  your hostess. (the pretty one with the long hair..)

I love coming here the food is always fantasic and the margaritas are tasty.. but your hostess is bringing down the buisness.

Given yesterday was Cinco de Mayo, and yes, you were packed..there is no excuse for the service the hostess was providing.

I shuffled my way around the U bar to the hostess station to ask about how long the wait would be.. only to find the hostess charging at me from the back. She then grabbed my elbow and snapped at me, "GO BACK TO THE BARREL." I could have been walking to the bathroom for all she knew.

If you get rid of her, I will consider coming back.
author: Caitlin W.

description:
I went here for the first time to meet a girlfriend for dinner and drinks.  I was pretty appalled with our overall dining experience.   We started with margaritas which were almost too strong to drink- and I like a strong margarita.  Perhaps too much cheap tequila went into them.  

We each ordered different tostada salads, which came out about 5 minutes after we ordered them (never a good sign).  I ordered chicken and it came out with beef.  After the confused waitress brought it back (are margaritas and 2 salads really that complicated?).   She finally brought out my salad with chicken.  Let me just say that this salad was virtually inedible.  Piles of watery shredded lettuce hid what little was underneath- scalding hot chicken slop and ice cold guacamole on top.  Ew.  To make matters worse, I burned my hand on the plate.   And this salad is $15??  No thanks.

Thoroughly disappointing experience.  Bad drinks, bad food, drab decor.  A knife stuck in my seat.  

Spend your hard earned money on the many great, inexpensive restaurants in this neighborhood and avoid this place!
author: Katie F.

description: Since I've moved from the neighborhood, this is one of the restaurants I do miss.  Had our holiday party here last night - 13 people.  Good food, good margaritas, lots of laughter.  A great evening.  Our servers were very attentive and both food and drinks were served quickly.  Judging by the fact that most people cleaned off their plates, I'd say it's safe to assume everyone liked their dinner - or they were all just very hungry.  :)
author: Denise M.

description:
I finally make it in for dinner on Saturday night and they messed it up.  We arrived right around 9:00pm and were seated immediately, cool.  Then almost immediately it all fell apart.  The hostess asked if she could move us because a large group had just arrived, ok I'll cooperate.  Then it took a few minutes to order but it was just in time.  Enter members of the local Golden Gate chapter of the World Adult Kickball Association (see associated review).  The food was actually pretty good and the atmosphere was better than Tommy's so that made it even more disappointing.

A few pointers for running a restaurant:
 - Separate couples from groups.
 - If you move someone make sure it's for the right reason.
   - Think about where you're moving them to (is it better or worse?).

My final analysis:
It was a slow night, the hostess saw an opportunity to make up for it but made some poor choices at the expense of the other patrons who like myself are now less likely to return.
author: Ryan P.

description:
In SF we are lucky enough to have three basic classes of Mexican restaurant loosely defined in the following categories: 1) Classy and expensive, 2) Cheap and Burrito and 3) Family and Margarita Dependent.  I love category number 3, especially when the food is decent, who comes here for the food anymore than you'd put gas in a car without an engine. 

The ideal category 3 Mexican restaurant has ridiculously strong and ridiculously cheap margaritas, fresh and spicy salsa, decent chips, and (in a perfect world) a patio to let the tequila- lime joy unfold on... A triplesec covered, tequila infused proscenium (if you will). 

Getting back to Tia's, it has a few things going for it off the bat: Weird soft white loungey lighting? Check. Huge round bar that seems to take up the entire restaurant? Check.  Hot hostess? Check.  Vaguely Andy Garcia bartender serving extra strong drinks to the ladies at the bar? Check. The margaritas are strong in their own right (especially the doubles) and the enchiladas are really quite good. I actually like these margaritas just as much as Tommy's... They give you two kinds of salsa with your chips too. All in all, I would be completely content here if they had a patio, which they don't. But no place is perfect and Tia Margarita does a really nice job being just what it is.
author: Matt C.

description:
Good solid Mexican food.  Personally, I didn't like the double Margarita and prefer the original - but that's me...  

I think it's a fun place for big crowds or if you like to watch sports at the bar.  Staff is friendly and there's classy guy who serves at the main dining area - he's a trip and worth the visit just to see him.
author: Bessie T.

description:
People in the Richmond don't have alot of choices for Mexican dining so it's no surprise when we get excited over the average fare at Tia's. Nothing wrong with the food here or the drinks but nothing deserving hyperbole either.

Large, dimly lit and casual, Tia is a fine place to bring a group of mates or your family. If you're alone, sit at the bar and talk to the locals. If you're with friends-of-friends (or worse, with your significant other's co-workers ;) ) asked to be sit up front in a booth. This is so you can see the flat-screen television, where baseball, basketball and other sports spool endlessly.

Regarding Tia vs Tommy's, without question Tommy's makes better margaritas but their food has a Yucatanean bent to it. This wonderful in it's own right but if what you're in the mood for is a more basic restaurant burrito, taco, etc you might find Tia more appealing.

Suggestions: if asked if you want hot or mild salsa get both. The hot is quite hot for some people but the mild has almost no heat (though it's tasty). For a change of pace, try the Guatemalan Tostada. It's topped with chunks of their Pollo Asada and the pineapple/sour dressing they pour over it really works well. You'll be greeted by an enormous mound of lettuce that may make you wonder if you did the right thing by listening to me, but dig deep down and you'll find there's black beans and lots of jack cheese sandwiched between two flour tortillas - more than enough substantial food to fill your tummy and then some.
author: Ben S.

description:
Try the shrimp gambias.  DIVINE.  Olive oil, fresh chopped garlic.. with sauteed shrimp then wrapped into little tortillas.  Delicious!  I've gone to this place about 3 times and I've loved it every single time.  I'm a big fan of Tommy's.. but this place is so much better.

It has the family/home feel to it.. a great bar.. service was a *tad* slow for our dishes (but it was just once like that).

I totally recommend this place (especially if you don't want to do the one hour wait at Tommy's).. this place is out of the way enough that it's always packed, but not brmming out the door with people.
author: Nancy H.

description:
Shockingly bad Mexican food that is grossly overpriced.  Anyone who comes here should be insulted.  Here in the heart of Aztlan, we should never accept this kind of ripoff.  Does tequila cause White people to lose their sense of taste?  It can be the only explanation of why this place exists and thrives as a business.

What's even worse is that the 2 worse Mexican restaurants I've been to in the Bay Area are right near each other - the other being the overhyped Tommy's on Geary.

If you've given this place or Tommy's more than 2 stars, you should hang your head in shame.
author: Surf R.

description:
This place is great.  I moved to the Outer Richmond just a couple of weeks ago and I can definately see that this place is going to become a regular staple in our dining out habit.
Great food and lots of it, decent margaritas, a fun atmosphere and fast service.
My only complaint is that it is a bit on the pricey side;  dinner for two with a couple of margaritas came in at around $45.00 (including tip).  But, whatever, with the amount of food you get, you should have enough leftover for lunch the next day.  So if you look at it that way, it's actually pretty cheap!
author: Mark G.

description:
SO GROSS.  our food came out and it was as if it had been sitting in the oven waiting for us to get there all day, and now that we finally arrived it just didn't want to go party anymore.  

but you know what?  we weren't fashionably late.
author: Nora B.

description:
The strongest, most potent margaritas can be found here at Tia Margarita.

I've been coming here for years and it's always a great time. The food is good and they give you plenty of chips. Chips and salsa are always a good thing.

The food is good, portions here are large, too. Probably to help you prevent a nasty hangover from the margaritas you've consumed.
author: Kelly R.

description: Went last night for the second time. Food/drinks/atmosphere were all sexy. The combination plates are crazy huge - enough for two people. My wife and I shared something involving enchiladas. One word to describe how I felt afterwards - "bloated". Luckily, after the 16 block walk home, my condition was downgraded to "really full".
author: Aaron Z.

description: I LOVE Tia Margarita! I've been going here for years. Favorites include the Guatemalan tostada, the chili con queso, the chicken appetizer with peanut sauce, the steak picata, and pollo asada, just to name a few. The margaritas are the real deal, none of the sugar mix and they are strong too!
author: R M.

description: I've come here once for Cinco de Mayo and a couple of times afterwards, oh and once when they were closed.  Sad sad day.  It's a fairly big place with more space around corners that you didn't know existed.  Sitting at the bar was fun and that's where I was for Cinco de Mayo.  I even won a t-shirt!  Have a Margarita, they're strong!  Be prepared to get wasted!
author: Rosalind S.

description:
TM is every bit as good as Tommy's but with more room and less of a wait. You can actually sit down, relax and have dinner here!

Margaritas - * * * *
Chips/salsa - * * * *
Gambas al ajillo - * * * * *
Service - * * * * *
Comfy booths - * * * * *
Secret location that lame Tommy's crowd hasn't discovered yet - * * * * *

Hurrah for MEXICAN DINNERS!
author: Dave P.

description:
Had dinner here last week w/ a group of friends.  Everything was good but nothing was too memorable.  I actually thought Tia Margaritas food & margaritas were very similar to La Barca.  The vibe  of course was nice b/c it lacked the marina crowd and the blaring music in the bar area.

I'd do the drive out here again when I want to have a mellow group dinner.  But not sure I'd go out of my way to have dinner here.
author: Amanda U.

description:
This place blows. They supposedly pride themselves on their margaritas but they are not good at ALL. I usually go for the standard margarita....on the rocks (salt or no salt - your choice). Once you go into the world of frozen margaritas you really don't know what you are getting - all that ice and syrup hides everything. But straight-up on the rocks? You know what you are getting.

At Tia Margarita...you are getting CRAP! The food sucks just as bad. If the margaritas were even half  good, the food wouldn't even matter so much b/c (let's face it) who the hell cares about the food at a Mexican joint if they are slingin' the agave the way it should be slung. 

Go a few blocks to Tommy's on Geary. The wait at Tommy's is long but it is worth the wait - and the margaritas there are divine.
author: Craig G.

description:
This place was ok. Not great, not horrible.

This is a very typical place that I grew up going to in SoCal. I found the food very average. I got the enchiladas which were good. They came with rice, beans and a small salad. The rice was different, not your typical mexican rice - but yellow and rather bland.

The atmosphere is relaxed and chill. The waitress was very nice, I think she was the owner. 

The chips and salsa was excellent. The portions are darn big. I found the prices a bit overpriced for average mexican.
author: Chili B.

description:
Went last night with the boyfriend because Tommy's was closed.  I was dissapointed.  I ordered enchiladas.  The service was good, so good our order came with in 5 minutes which is a bad sign for me.  Upon eating I realized I was right because my enchiladas were cold and the cheese inside congealed.  The sauce was mediocre, not very flavorfull.  I ordered my enchiladas with no onions and they came correct but atop my black beans was a huge blob of onion salsa that commom sense would dictate I did not want.  The rice is not vegetarian which I would not judge them on just wanted to let people know.  
The margaritas were not large but ungodly strong. 
Seemed like a real old folks hang out, boyfriend and I joked it was filled with the rogue elderly peeps that didn't end up at the Pacific cafe.
author: Kaylee T.

description: This is our favorite neighborhood Mexican restaurant.  Tasty margaritas and great food. I love the red salsa here.  It can get a bit too loud when crowded but one can always go on a quieter weekday evening.
author: Kim M.

description: Love love love the food.  The specials are like nothing I have tasted at a Mexican restaurant.  This place is like family.  The more you go, the more you are remembered and the more you become one of the family.  It is my happy place.
author: Shauna G.

description:
When it comes to mexican food out here in the Richmond District it gets narrowed down to a couple. Tia Maragrita is the best mexican restaurant in the district with delicious double margaritas and food.  

The service on the other hand is nothing less than a joke. I apologize the bartender is absolutely amazing doing everything back there with a smile and a joke. The servers in the back are just a joke, it's just ridiculous, when you go there. The servers are so slow it's easier and quicker just to go to the bar to get a drink. 

Although the food is pretty darn good for the area, Alex the busser was the only good service besides the bar.
author: Nathan H.

description: This place is a million times better than Tommy's Mexican Restaurant.  They're salsa is very tasty,  They serve HUGE portions and I definitley left very full. The service was good and the waiters were very attentive.  After ordering, the food came out in no time.  All in all, this place is good and more importantly way better than Tommy's.  I was a happy customer.
author: christina c.

description: awesome little spot in the richmond.  ordered tamlies and a garlic prawn dish, portions were HUGE!  only downside was that food took a while to come out and by the time it finally did, we were all full off of the chips and salsa (which was also pretty tasty).  will definitely be back
author: Damien R.

description:
This place was EXACTLY what I was looking for.  That's why the five stars.  

It seemed like all the Mexican places I found on Yelp were either burrito joints or sit-down restaurants with high-dollar interior Mex food.  I wanted a Mexican restaurant like the ones I grew up eating as a SoCal suburb girl.  Americanized Mexican combinations that are REALLY good.  Nothing fancy; just solid (traditional chile relleno beats out one with goat cheese and pine-nuts in my book).  A sit-down restaurant that served chips and salsa right off the bat.  Has great homemade guacamole.  And an enchilada with good enchilada sauce (not mole sauce or super-mild red sauce).  This place was perfect.  

Well, the rice IS kinda a mystery.  The flavor is like Chicken Rice-a-roni but milder.  But the beans are deliciously topped with that sizzling white cheese.  And I recommend asking them for HOT sauce.  If you mix it with the salsa they give you, it's TOPS.  

I had a chicken taco, cheese enchilada and shredded beef and bean burrito (for a combo plate, the burrito is was HUGE).  I had some of my boyfriend's chile relleno.  Everything was awesome.  The flan was perfect too.

Go here for the best mexican family restaurant I've seen yet in these parts.  It's still a BIT pricey ($15 for my 3-item combo) but I have another meal out of it and it was the bomb.  And their margaritas are nice and strong and not heavy on the mixer.  Damn this place rocks.
author: Staci M.

description:
I have heard wonderful things about this restaurant from my co-worker.  She goes here like once a week, and says the margaritas are awesome and strong.  I was excited to check it out for myself.

Came here already a bit tipsy, and had already had dinner.  So, I just had beer.  My girlfriend ordered chicken super nachos.  I love nachos.  Anyhow, my drunk ass starts eating the nachos once they arrive, and then I realize.... hmmmm, this doesn't taste like chicken.  They gave us meat instead of chicken.  The only problem is, I don't eat cow.  So, I was disgusted.  I know, I know it's my drunk ass' fault.  But still....  

I really like the restaurant itself.  It reminds me of Mexican restaurants in Dallas, where I'm from.  Also, the staff was very nice.  My drunk ass forgot my jacket, and they came outside to find me to give it to me.  Well, we were a bit wasted and left a 40% tip, so yeah, I guess they wanted to be nice back.  

I will be back, this time to eat.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Gotta love those margaritas..... yes it is in their name and to say they do it justice is well..... selling them short. The food is good but alas, no Mole for me meester Mole but what cha gonna do? 

Suffice it to say I like to sit in the bar and they do let you eat there so its all good.

Cheers,

E
author: H Edward C.

description: It's a great neighborhood go to spot in the Richmond.  The fajitas are a must.  The margarita is decent but they don't use fresh agave like Tommys.  The bartenders are great and it's always nice to sit at the bar and enjoy the scene.
author: Hawk M.

description: Was here just the week before their 50th Anniversary bash and nothing has changed--------it's still one of the best places ever! Food is just wonderful, margaritas are perfect, and both staff & management are as attentive and friendly as ever. Happy 50th and may you have many more years to come.
author: M W.

description:
It's a family restaurant -- what are people expecting?! A five-star experience?

It's fine! The people are nice, the food is good -- not amazing, but good -- and if you want an enchilada, there are so many varieties! And the plates are HUGE. If you're hungry, this is THE place to go if you're in the Richmond.

Also, if you're lucky enough to get the crazy older lady as your waitress, you get stories for weeks! She once served us and when we told her that wasn't our food she yelled, "THEN DON"T TOUCH IT, I'll be back!" 
And she did, and she swapped for the right plates and served the correct plates to the right people. It was funny and not a problem at all.

One small thing: I like the food better here and the margaritas at Tommy's. If you're looking for food, come here. If you're looking for a pitcher of margaritas, go to Tommy's. They do Not serve pitchers at Tias.
author: Sapana S.

description: aye caramba!...omg!...margaritas fuertes!..potent margaritas warning!...suaza blanco tequila cascade...margarita glass grande por double $diez...$ten double plus extra tequila shot large....endless chips y salsa rojo...red salsa es fantastico!....nachos con queso, carne y frijoles...meaty, beany and cheesy excellente!....outer sunset tia margarita mexican....mexican meals standard...pool of brown frijoles refritos y rice....saucing and cheesing covered mexican meals....uninterested and boring....arriba! arriba! andale! andale!...dos double margaritas!....two more margaritas!
author: Hen A.

description:
came here on cinco de mayo after tommy's, to try to find a place that wasn't freakishly packed. it was crowded as well, but at least we could breath. if you wanted to eat, though, the wait was about 2 hours. but we skipped that, and went straight to the bar. we ordered 3 top-shelf margarita's. we were skeptical when we saw it how small the cups were and how much ice he put. but, hot-damn, that was a strong fucking drink! and half the price of tommy's. we had been swallowing drinks since 11am, but we all struggled with this one. 

food-wise, i came here once before, but i cant even remember what i ate. but my best buddy swears that the food here is good. and considering he is a restaurant owner, i'd believe him. he also says that the service is mediocre. and yeah, the hostess was pretty much a bitch. oh, and if you order a corona, they give you a poncho to put around it. funny!
author: Andrew T.

description:
I love this place.  I'm from AZ, and place is my mexican food home away from home.  It has all the elements I remember from AZ, vinyl booths, dim lighting, great bar and yummy fajitas!  

ps-  the margs will kick your butt!
author: Stephanie J.

description:
I love Tia. This is definitely a locals joint, but all are welcome. The food and drinks are fine, but nothing to write home about. Because I don't LOVE the food, Tia is a 3 star joint. However, it certainly feels like more stars while you are there. 

There are a few reasons why you should frequent Tia Margarita:

- You live in the Richmond and love Mexican food
- There is a really cool bar with lots of room (I can eat there alone and not feel like a loser or I can bring friends and have a place to sit)
- The place has great vibes (friendly staff and clientele) 
- You have kids/baby and want to eat out
- You need a "Cheers" of your own

Tip: A double margarita is the way to go. Just say: "Double on the rocks", 'nough said.

Bottom line: Tia offers a great all around experience and has been around and in the same family for decades.
author: Judd L.

description:
I went to Tia Margarita last night with as a party of three. We started off with maragaritas which were strong and satisfying as well as only $4.95. The chips were good, but the salsa looked and tasted like it had come from a bottle...not bad, just not noteworthy.

The menu is fairly simple Sonoran fare (tacos, enchiladas, etc.). Between the three of us, we had chiles rellenos, enchiladas, tamales, and a chimichanga (not really Mexican, I know). The tamales were excellent: fresh and with lots of carne. The chiles rellenos were about a 7 on a 1-10 scale as were the enchiladas (a bit bland) and the chimichanga.

The rice was odd in that it looked and tasted like rice pilaf. It was definitely not traditional Mexican rice...although it tasted fine. The refried beans were also bit bland.

Good Mexican food in SF is very hard to find, but by SF standards, I would give this place 3.5 stars. (it would get two stars in San Diego). Still, it's worth visiting as the food, although not particularly noteworthy, is satisfying. The lively crowd is also a plus.
author: Michael W.

description:
I love this place anytime I'm at my girlfriends, which is near it, I go. I love the food and atmosphere. Last time I had a margarita there it was awful and that was about 4 years ago. I see they've introduced different bar tenders and different liquor and notice they are trying to improve the drinks. I'll try one next time and let you know.

I will not go to Tommy's anymore, last time I was there was Cinco De Mayo about 3 years ago around 5:30 not even crowded yet and the margaritas were horrible. Plus  their food has never been that good.
author: Carter R.

description: OK peeps, listen up. Food reviews of mexican restaurants should not be compared to the level of service, quality, and culinary genious as say, Michael Mina. That being said, Tia is a great place to kick back and have a seriously delish mexican platter of goodness. The food is hot, cheesy, satisfying, and there's a lot of it. Their top shelf margs are pretty hard to beat too, no mixers here. I will say the service is lackluster, but who cares. It's a great place to go with a bunch of friends so it doesn't bother me when my server just does her/his job w/o the frills. The bartenders are kinda weird, I agree. Kind of strange how stressed out they seem squeezing limes for a living, but whatevs.  I love the 2 salsas they serve with the chips too.
author: Kylie S.

description: Funky little spot. Great margarita of course :)
author: rachel g.

description:
"Your wait will be 30-45 minutes.  Okay, so you can either wait outside or grab drinks at the tequila bar."  How does a cute hostess always abate me, even though I know the wait will be double whatever they say? I should know better than to be beguiled by a nice pair of  tits and ass

"Your wait will be 10-15 minutes" she says with smile that paints my cheeks red.  I already waited Forty fucking Five minutes.  My friends convinced me to eat elsewhere since I had an English bloke who had a flight to catch within the hour, so time was of an essence.

"Just wait a minute for your table to be prepared," the unattractive and well aged hostess at Tia's remarked.  Now that's the kind of service I like to hear.  

"We're kind of in a rush, could we just order now," which is what I told the waiter, making me feel so pretentious.  He didn't mind.  Chips and salsa, hmm, had to hold us over for 15 minutes until the waiter served our entrees--what steward service!

"Well, I can say I am full, but am I satisfied," the type of question you never want your girlfriend to ask herself after having sex with you OR eating food.  To be quite frank, I was not satisfied.  After eating Mexican , my tongue should feel like the dance floor of a fiesta.
author: John P.

description:
I like this place,not just for the food but the atmosphere..the customers to the people who work here. The place is really enjoyable and you can tell when you walk in ...you view the people at the bar and they are laughing and having a good time,.ofcourse they are drunk out of their minds..It's all GOOD. Every time that I have gone it has been a good crowd inside and while I have been there people flock in and out.

Customers are super friendly too. I like this place overall and constantly tell other people about it.
author: Mattee M.

description:
After hearing many wonderful reviews through word of mouth I decided to finally give Tia Margarita's a try.  I figured the reviews came from trusted friends and how can you go wrong with Mexican after all I am one!

Warning numero uno. If you walk into an authentic Mexican restaurant and you and your friend are the only Mexicans in the place turn and run!

 The food at Tia Margaritas was far from appetizing; in fact it was as far from Mexican as Mexican food could be. I order the combination place (the small combo plate, you have a choice of three), which consisted of Spanish rice, refried beans, 1 enchilada, and 1 chile relleno (you have a choice of two items to go with your sides. 1 enchilada, 1 Taco, 1 chile relleno, 1 Fluata or 1 burrito).

Now I am not sure were the chef went to cooking school but it definitely did not specialize in Mexican cuisine. The Spanish rice was made with Risotto style rice, the salad came covered in Salsa, and the refried beans, basically tasted like a 50 cent can of refried beans.

The chips and so-called salsa did little for me. The salsa seemed to be made from ketchup and cocktail sauce with a hint of chopped onions.

The staff was friendly and nice and was very attending, and polite.

Unfortunately the only thing authentic about Tia Margarita's was there selection of beer.

This place should change there name to Aunt Margaret's and their Menu. Save your money and walk around the block to Gordo's.
author: Chuy C.

description:
I really have no good basis for critiquing Mexican food as my background is White girl/hawaiian/portuguese.  And in Hawaii, my homeland, we grew up with touristy Mexican food and the ever infamous Taco Bell.  But, I do know a damn good margarita when I get one.  Tia gets all 5 of my stars for their Margaritas alone.  Freshly made, no nasty mixers, and a great selection of Te"kill"ya!

Parking sucks so plan on parking far away on a busy night or carpooling.  I would take off a star for this normally but, not with Tia because it's really not their fault and if there were any more parking than there would be way too many people.

I love the food and the family vibe/family run feeling of this place too.
author: Kyky A.

description:
I used to live a block from Clement Street and had hundreds of tasty restaurants to love, but kept going back to Tia's. The food is good, the margaritas are inspirational. And the staff are very friendly. It's a true neighborhood place, with a relaxed and happy atmosphere. 

Weekends are jumping and Friday and Saturday dinner hour will mean a bit of a wait for your table. But you can get a margarita at the bar and watch sports on two TVs in the front room. You know it says something when the locals line up to eat here, while there are so many other restaurants to choose from nearby.

MARGARITAS!
author: Sira A.

description: Went one night - on a crowded Friday night - with a bunch of small children. Hostess was very rude (children were largely well-behaved). I chalked it up to her having a bad night and we went back without kids a few weeks later. Same hostess - same rudeness. Not going back.
author: Lauren C.

description: A solid neighborhood place. My only beef is that I wish it would stay open a hour or two later (at least the bar). But I guess that comes with the territory when you are in a relatively quiet neighborhood.
author: Nick H.

description: The margaritas are okay, but the food isn't. Maybe I lived in the Mission too long, but the food doesn't stack up in any way to San Francisco mexican, and the rice is more like white rice than spanish rice. The tortillas were soggy and the chile relleno and enchilada were quite bland. On top of that it was too pricey for what you're getting. I'd go back to sit at the bar and have a margarita with chips and salsa. The chips really were pretty good, but wouldn't be ordering a meal again.
author: V K.

description: I love me some Tia!  This is hubby and my's go-to comfort food place.  And no, we are not of the South of the Border persuasion.  It's just some serious Mexican comfort food.  We don't go there weekly, but pretty often and they remember what we normally order.  Okay, maybe we _do_ go there a pretty often if they remember what we order.   My only wish is that they would sell me some of the salsa to take home.  I know, I know, it's not that spicy (I'm white and I like it mild), but I don't know what they lace it with, but it is seriously addictive!  Great margaritas, big plates of food, love the staff...they are family.
author: Kim S.

description: My all time favorite Mexican food.  The Carne Asada is by far the best I've had anywhere!  The margaritas are excellent too!
author: A P.

description:
it was a friday  night and the place was already swarming with customers waiting to be seated and drinking to their heart desires.
the first thing you will see here is the bar which is the main focal point at this restaurant.

so just like the others who were waiting for their table, i ordered myself a "one shot top shelf margarita." it was intense & worthy...whoa!..awesome!!!

we did not really waited that long and so funny man cesar called my name and lead us to their medium-sized dining area at the back.
i ordered a bottle of corona for myself again...and this time while waiting for the food.

the combination plate (large) which i picked: enchilada, tamale & flauta was kind of a  let-down..it was the dry tamale that made my dining experience kaput. the rest of the food was mediocre.

his plate of the chef's platter was worst than mine! the beef was chewy, the chicken was dry and the tiny shrimps was just ok...it was really garlicky.

i would say that this place will better off as a drinking establishment and serving just mex  appetizers...really!
author: Nelle A.

description:
Hmmm...a few key pieces of advice:
-If you are not coming here to drink, don't bother coming
-Don't order the Tia Tostada salad or any of the salads for that matter. In fact, don't eat anything but the chips, salsa, guacamole, and sauteed chicken (on the app menu) and wash all of that down with about a dozen delicious margaritas.
-If you are in the company of small children, you will be drawn to TM because it appears that the noise of a small child might be easily absorbed by the raucous crowd. Your instincts are correct but it will be so noisy and claustrophobic that even the most precocious and outgoing little people will be overwhelmed. And you will probably find yourself overwhelmed too.
-Sit at the bar. The table and chair configuration is awkward and hard to navigate and the back dining room feels like a cave. 
-Don't bother if you're looking to get in and out fast. Service is excellent and every last person working here was incredibly helpful and pleasant. That being said, there will still be a long wait for entrees to arrive at the table.
-This place felt like Spring Break by 7 p.m. on a recent Saturday night. Which may explain why my 2-year-old partner in crime kept trying to take his shirt off.
author: Autumn K.

description: A great neighborhood spot.  You have to relax and not be in a rush.  My favorite margaritas in the city. The empanadas are amazing.
author: B N.

description: I really liked this place the first time I went and have liked it less with each successive visit.  The food is OK, but it should be better considering how few sit-down Mexican restaurants San Francisco has.  It also has an interesting layout that goes pretty well with the dark Mexican-restaurant thing--at least it's what I'm used to from similar places in L.A.  The best thing about it, though, is that it carries RC Cola instead of Coke or Pepsi.  How cool is that?  OK, I'm bumping it up a star for that reason--well, no I'm not, but it is cool.  It's also in a cool part of the Richmond.
author: John S.

description:
THE WORST MEXICAN FOOD EVER! I ate their yesterday (8-3) for dinner. 

The chips and salsa- chips were okay... they were cold. Salsa was gross way over seasoned; the red salsa tasted like salted garlic. The green salsa was pretty good.

Margarita- single, blended. brought to me watery and tasted like watery tequila with well mix. $4.75

Guacamole- over seasoned and pureed I'm sure. there was no sign of any other ingredient beside avocado and garlic salt.

Chille relleno- tasted okay but they were itty bitty and the representation was very poor. and the sauce tasted like raviolli sauce. $12.50

rice- pretty sure it was not mexican rice but rather some stove top stuff! that's the san francisco treat!

beans- really salty and just did not add to any part of the meal.

salad with tomato sauce- eww didn't even touch it!

so what did i eat with my 25 dollar meal? a gross, watery and weak margarita, 2 lousy, small chile rellenos, half the guacamole, 4 forkfuls of rice, 2 forkfuls of beans, and chips.

I would not recommend going here at all to any body. just go around the corner to gordos and have a burrito. it is WAY better and cheaper.
author: Maria G.

description: The best part of eating here was the red salsa that came with the chips. Extremely tasty and delightful. Other than that, Tia Margarita's was a let down. Our drink orders were taken immediately then for the next 15 minutes...nothing. No drinks, no water, no entree orders, nothing. I finally ordered a combo of chicken tamale and a flauta. While the flauta was decent, the tamale was surprisingly flavorless. Surely not worth $13. Though the lady serving us was very nice, I don't think I'll be coming back here again.
author: Raymond P.

description: BEST MARGARITAS...order the double fresh lime, blended. $10 --FRANCISCO is the best bar guy...he rocks. I live nearby...THE food is your typical  americanized cheesey Mex food. skip the food and go for the margs.
author: Bing B.

description: It ain't Tommy's, it ain't Puerto....boo.  The food was blah blah bland.  I had to cover my enchilda in hot sauce to taste anything.  I eventually gave up and guzzled weak margaritas.  Our server was nice, but she clearly was frustrated that she had to serve a party of 7.  I'm sorry, but that is your job.  I could perhaps understand if our party was rude and obnoxious, but we were patient and friendly and she just was rude and annoyed with us from the start.  I would honestly rather eat and Chevy's.  The salsa and chips are better, even the cocktails are stronger.  That's for sure.  Puerto....how I long for you!
author: Justine D.

description:
This restaurant is a dud! I have not been this disappointed with a restaurant since I found a paper clip in a Thai Fried Rice dish at Lemongrass on Polk back in 2005. 

We found one of those free San Francisco restaurant guides a wee while back, I forget which one exactly. This place was written up as being one of the cities best Mexican eateries, so we were eager to try it out one Sunday afternoon and even took a friend. When we arrived there appeared to be a few people sat in the front of the restaurant and there was a nice bustling ambiance. All seemed well. This little old lady lead us away from the 'atmospheric' front room into a darkly lit back room and stuck us completely alone in the back of the restaurant completely away from everyone else (and there were plenty of tables up front). We thought that was, well, a bit odd. I ordered Chimichangas (I think that's what they're called), and what I got was a plate of shredded lettuce, Lay's Mild Salsa strewn across it as if it were spilled, a cold pile of Uncle Ben's Basmati Rice complete with neon yellow coloring and three tiny shrivelled up Taquito's that resembled those ones you get from Trader Joe's and microwave for a minute (y'know the ones, we've all bought 'em)

Disgusting? Yes pretty much, certainly if you take into account how much I paid for this. And when I asked for a soda refill, Grandma Waitress threw a hissy fit my way shouting at me that "there are NO refills" and that "I must pay for another one!!" Well I never! My boyfriend Oscar is of Mexican decent, and therefor knows what real Mexican food looks and tastes like. He said that his grandmother would have had a heart attack if she had seen how repulsive, cheap and sloppy the Mexican food was here! Because that lady knows how to whip up some tacos, something apparently Tia Margarita lacks. Everyone elses food sucked just as bad, and also came complete with a serving of Uncle Ben's and a whole lotta attitude.
